name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday 28 January 2015 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 5 February 2015 in accordance with Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. The following amendments have been requested to this draft: Monday: the political groups have asked for today's sitting to be extended until 10 p.m. (Parliament adopted the motion)

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, can I make a request to the Conference of Presidents? One of the most important opportunities for MEPs is that provided by the one-minute speeches, where we can raise issues of particular interest to our own constituencies or to the European Union. Half an hour at each part-session is a very short period of time and I would ask that the rules be changed so that the Conference would have an opportunity to extend that to one hour when time allows.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr! The one-minute speeches are scheduled for today's agenda. They have a lot of time afterwards. If you think that we should regulate this differently in the Rules of Procedure, I take note of your request. We will discuss this in the Conference of Presidents. But first of all, there is enough time tonight for the one-minute speeches. Tuesday: No changes. Wednesday: With regard to the debate on the "Humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria as a result of the violence perpetrated by ISIS", the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance is asking for the title to be changed to "Humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, especially in the IS context."

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would hope that this is pretty uncontroversial. We think that this is a poorly entitled resolution before we have even started on it.  To look at just the violence caused by IS, which is of course deplorable, is to miss the fact that there is an awful lot of other violence going on within these two countries which is causing an ongoing humanitarian situation. To focus this simply on IS, we think, misses a point and misses a wider agenda that would be addressed by ‘The humanitarian crisis in Iraq and Syria, in particular in the IS context’, because it is right that we should take account of IS, of course, but there is a much wider picture which this House should really be cognisant of.  So I would hope that colleagues will support this – I hope – sensible change.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Wednesday (continued): The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is asking for a Commission statement on energy interconnections to be put on the agenda.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I am intervening in the place of Mr Melo, my colleague, who has not yet arrived. I am therefore making his interpreter to ask that a debate with resolution on energy interconnections be added to the agenda of our plenary session.  In the context of the completion of the internal energy market, the development of an interconnected European network seems to me to be really essential, it concerns not only the countries of the Iberian peninsula, but also the Baltic countries. It would be good to alert the European Commission to the urgent need for such measures.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Mr President, you know very well, the Member States have set targets for the interconnection of networks, wanting the single market for energy in Europe, and the networks are at the heart of this single market and the Union's Energy Union, which is why the PPE Group is having a resolution debate on this subject.

name: Dan NICA

The first is that already in the ITRE Committee there is an initiative report dealing with exactly the same subject and which will be presented in the period immediately following, and the second very strong reason is that in just two weeks we will have the plan presented by Vice-President Šefčovič, which, of course, is a very broad plan which also includes this very important transport problem and which will resolve the whole project to be presented by Mr Šefčovič the whole issue, including that relating to the two countries of the Iberian peninsula and the Baltic countries, but also with reference to the countries of the Mediterranean and those of south-eastern Europe. And I think it is good to wait for this plan, it will be discussed in the session of 25 February and we will certainly have the opportunity to discuss such an important subject in the whole issue of the European energy market.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Wednesday (continued): I have received a request from a required number of individual Members to put on the agenda a Statement by the Commission on the 70th anniversary of the Yalta Agreement with a resolution. Mr Marek Jurek has asked to speak in order to justify the request.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by At our meeting, exactly 70 years have passed since the Yelta conference, which decided the fate of the whole of Europe for half a century. For half of Europe's countries that have retained their freedom, it has created a permanent military threat. Our homeland and many other central European countries have taken away their freedom. The Baltic States took away their state being and, in relation to Germany, prepared the way for their division. We are convinced that the importance of this event deserves the European Parliament, through respect for European history, to celebrate this event with a serious debate examining the lessons learned for the present day from the Yaltaan tragedy, and for us to conclude this debate with the adoption of the relevant resolution.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, I think everyone is real about what the Yalta conference for Europe represented, but I prefer not to mix genders. We are here in an elected assembly, a political assembly. We are not in an assembly of historians. For my part, I am loath to use historical events to write history in one way or another, which serves the interests of one or the other. I believe that these debates should be left to historians and all those who are interested in them , and there are certainly many people here who are interested in them , but I do not think it is entirely appropriate for this House to be the place for debate and resolution on the interpretation of history.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking On several occasions, the European Parliament has dealt with historical events. We have paid a great deal of attention to the anniversary of the outbreak of World War I. No one who respects European solidarity and respects the truth can pass indifferently to Yalta, which has drastically divided Europe and pushed european unity away by 50 years. This is an extremely important fact not only for Romanians, Bulgarians, Latvians, Lithuanians, Estonians, Poles, Czechs, Slovaks, Croats, but for all people who respect European solidarity. I therefore call on my colleagues from all political formations – the Christian Democrats, the Socialists, the Greens and all other political formations – not to be indifferent to one of the most important events in European history.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the Commission's expert group on the enforcement of intellectual property rights by Pavel Svoboda, Jean-Marie Cavada and Angel Dzhambazki on behalf of the Legal Affairs Committee (O-000001/2015 – B8-0102/2015) (2014/2972(RSP)).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: author. - Mr President, let me briefly present the oral question on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs. As you know, this committee is responsible for the area of intellectual property rights. I dare to say that this area is of great interest for a large number of committee members who understand the importance of intellectual property rights in the 21st century. I think that the Commission is of the same view, and I would like to thank the Commission for its quick reaction when providing us with its understanding of the issues raised in our question. While drafting this question, we have been motivated by the fact that, given the importance of intellectual property rights for the future growth of the European Union, we should use all our instruments in the most effective way in order to get the best information available. We could use the information obtained not only for the purposes of enforcement evaluation, but also, for example, while thinking about the future reform of copyright. That is why we would like to ask the Commissioner to confirm that there will be no duplication of tasks between the observatory and the group of experts which the Commission would like to establish, according to the action plan on the enforcement of intellectual property rights, and that no related unnecessary financial implications will take place, and to confirm that Parliament will be invited to send experts who will take part in this proposed group of experts as observers.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I want to thank the Committee on Legal Affairs and especially its Chairman, Mr Svoboda, for their question, because the answer will allow me to maybe explain more and put a decision in context. You asked about the setting up of a group of experts on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. So maybe just one short remark putting the decision into context. Markets and technologies are constantly changing, and we need to keep up with them. We need to keep on finding new solutions to breaches of IPR, and we need to be targeted. We need to develop new enforcement tools. It is for this reason – and also because Member States cannot go alone with the issue – that in July last year an expert group was set up. It was a core part of our ten-point plan to improve IPR enforcement, and the Member States welcomed it. Let me turn to the specifics of your question. First you asked about the tasks of the group and how they add value to the work of the Observatory. Second, you asked about the financial implications and whether there will be duplication.  The expert group, it has to be stressed, has a strict mission. It is to advise and assist the Commission on policy initiatives. Its members are the national authorities responsible for national IP policies, and it is to exchange experience and good practice. It will not gather data or conduct studies itself. Instead it will rely on work done at national, EU and international level, including, of course, the work done by the Observatory. This is completely different, as we see it, from the role of the Observatory. The Observatory is there to facilitate and support the practical enforcement work. That includes improving understanding and raising awareness of the impact of IPR infringements, providing training, promoting enforcement tools and technology, and helping national enforcement authorities to work together. The Observatory supports national authorities, the private sector and EU institutions. Part of this is data collection; the data collected and reported by the Observatory supports the work of the Commission and the Member States. So the expert group focuses – just to repeat – on policy, best practices and monitoring, and the Observatory focuses on the day-to-day enforcement and the collection of data. They do not duplicate. On the contrary, they are complementary. So the group will not result in unnecessary expenditure. Third, you wanted confirmation that you could send experts to an expert group meeting, and the answer is yes, absolutely you can – you will be very welcome. We apply the framework document on relations between the European Parliament and the European Commission, but equally important, I think, is that you should be part of this body and participate in this work. We have to work together on IPR enforcement. It would be really helpful if you would follow the group actively. I will also listen to your questions and remarks, because I think that it will help our future work. I hope that reassures you and answers your questions.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This question seems to be an unfounded question, but we are really expecting here in the European Parliament, but also in many other environments, the broad reform of intellectual property rights announced by the European Commission – hence every action taken by the Commission is also closely watched in the European Parliament. The establishment of a group of experts is neither new nor anything out of the question. Our question has been addressed to the Commission only for this purpose, not only to check whether there is overlapping of the scope of the work of the Observatory (OHIM) in Alicante of this expert group, because it would be completely unnecessary to duplicate the same activities. We are going a step further – namely, we are asking not only whether this is a duplication, but also how much these institutions, both operating for the same European Union, will work together. The question is that some of the experts appointed by the European Commission to this expert group are also the same experts who work for the Observatory (OHIM). It seems absolutely essential that everyone can benefit from the information and experience of both the Observatory and the expert group, including the European Parliament and, above all, the Committee on Legal Affairs, which will be responsible here in Parliament for the proposed reform in the area of intellectual property rights.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Many studies confirm the important contribution of intellectual property rights to the EU economy. This is also reflected by the Commission's 2014 Action Plan, including the plan to set up an additional expert group on this. We Socialists and Democrats support the concern of the EU Action Plan. Infringement of intellectual property rights causes great economic damage. The OECD estimates that the global economy loses a total of around €200 billion each year as a result of infringements of intellectual property rights. After all, it is particularly important to us, as the Social Democrats and the S&D Group, that the interests of cultural workers are particularly taken into account. This should be taken more into account in the action plan, and this should also be more closely focused on the expert group. If the Commission comes to this conclusion, we Social Democrats, as socialists and democrats, are calling for a clear description of the tasks, as has just been done in part by the Commission. I think that would be a good thing if we, as the Committee on Legal Affairs and parliamentarians, could read this again in writing. It is essential that both MEPs and civil society actors are involved, such as consumer protection organisations, trade unions and, in particular, cultural workers. In our view, the establishment of a group of experts requires close cooperation with parliamentary bodies.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr Presiding, Honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, it is important to emphasise the importance of intellectual property protection and the very negative impact of infringements on this property for the economy as a whole, for the workforce, for the incentive for innovation and creativity.  Let's not also open the conversation about the informal economy, which benefits from the lack and non-compliance with the necessary legislation in this field. Of course, good enforcement of intellectual property rights is needed, but not at the taxpayer's expense, not wasting public money, which in low-standard countries would mean the livelihoods of hundreds of families.  Is it really necessary to set up this group, provided that the Observatory is already engaged in this and one of its working groups is fully engaged precisely in the enforcement and protection of intellectual property rights? The Observatory even has its own observers in the European Parliament, including me, and the expert group does not even foresee this. Don't you think it is at least more practical for those directly elected to have an observation on the work of this expert group so that we can report and report to our colleagues in the European Parliament and to our constituents on the work done in this area?  I had the honour and pleasure of attending the Observatory's plenary session in October last year and received the necessary information about their activities, for which, of course, I thank and believe in the efforts for future fruitful work. The Committee on Legal Affairs also invites them frequently to meetings where they provide information on activity and development in the field. Again, I ask, is further waste needed and how can this need for the establishment of a new such expert group be explained?

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, copyright protects itself in the author's life. The period of seventy years for the protection of the property dimension of copyright relating to an intellectual creation after the death of the respective author constitutes a legal and economic aberration. Moreover, it is an inadmissible privilege in the present day, without any acceptable justification. This long period of time does not protect the authors but rather the people who have no legitimate connection to the act of creation. It prolongs, after the death of the author, an illegitimate situation of monopoly exclusivity that, being understandable during the life of the creator, becomes unacceptable after his death, because it prevents, or at least restricts, the enjoyment of the work by the general public. This privilege is more proper to privatistic conceptions of the time of Napoleon's Civil Code than of a time like the present, in which it seeks to democratize access to culture and the widespread enjoyment of works of art. The current legal regime prolongs for too long a situation of monopoly exclusivity in favor of the heirs of the intellectual creator, so that only they, or whom they designate, can disclose the work. At the limit, they may even prevent its dissemination, that is, they may even prevent his work from being disclosed or known to the public for seventy years. Let us see if this scheme applied, for example, to drug patents, where the medicine could be protected for seventy years after the author's death. For all this, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there is an urgent need to reduce the 70-year period to a limit of not more than twenty or thirty years.  An end to protectionism, rather the freedom to enjoy intellectual creations and works of art.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I welcomed the oral question to the Commission on the initiative of the Committee on Legal Affairs. I consider it essential that the European Parliament be sufficiently involved in the work of experts in the field of modernising intellectual property law, who must respond adequately to the rapid development and development of this sector, particularly as regards the Internet. However, I would add a little bit to this question. The area of intellectual property law is an extremely important area, given that more than 7 million Europeans are directly employed in the cultural and artistic sector in Europe and a sector that attracts young workers – 19% of jobs are filled by people under the age of 30. The sector grew in terms of employment despite the economic crisis. I would therefore like to ask the Commission what its idea is of reforming intellectual property rights, how it can maintain an intellectual property system in the future that maintains creativity and ensures a return on investment, and how it will strike a balance between the legal protection of authors and creators and public access to works. Last but not least, I would like to be given an answer to the question of how the TTIP negotiations will affect the protection and development of intellectual property from an EU perspective.

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in December 2014 Commissioner Oettinger went on record to answer three questions I had tabled under Rule 130 regarding this current incarnation of the Commission’s group of experts on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. He announced he would have the list of members of this expert group published along with ‘all relevant documents, including agendas and minutes of each meeting’. So far, 13 out of the 28 Member State authorities remain unlisted in the register entry for this expert group. No minutes for the first and only meeting so far have been published. Meeting documents of this first meeting also remain unpublished. So, while the answer to my parliamentary question came from Commissioner Oettinger and not from the Commissioner in charge, the open task remains the same. Therefore, do get serious on the transparency and proper record-keeping of this group. Will the Commission commit itself to deliver these basic requirements on a specific date?  Along with my fellow colleagues from the Committee on Legal Affairs, I agree that it is important that there is no duplication in the setting-up of this expert group and the OHIM Observatory. The Commission should also comment on such a possible overlap and the apparent disconnect of this expert group from its predecessors also set up by the Commission in previous years. The burden of proof is on the Commission to show that this expert group will go beyond the OHIM Observatory and its rather extensive mandate. If such an added benefit exists, it would rather call for the readjustment of the EU Observatory mandate. So far no observer status has been given to Members of this Parliament but there are no procedural reasons not to, as Article 53 of the Commission decision on setting up these expert groups allows the Chair to assign observer status to every entity listed in Rule 8(3) of the horizontal rules for Commission expert groups. Therefore, the Commission should assign observer status to Parliament and it should do so immediately. The Committee on Legal Affairs will be happy to follow the work of this working group very actively. Finally, I would like to know if the purpose of this expert group is about to go in the same direction as that of the OHIM Observatory, whose work programme for this year expressly includes the public domain and open licensing. It is very important when developing measures for intellectual property enforcement to analyse how they affect creative works in the public domain or under a free licence model.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, adequate and intelligent protection of intellectual property rights, which encourages investment, innovation and creativity, is a fundamental tool to help Europe emerge from the crisis. In this context, commercial infringements of intellectual property rights are extremely harmful and constitute a great danger in many respects. It is particularly a matter of particular alarm that these offences are mainly attributable to criminal organisations and mafias throughout Europe, which make huge profits from counterfeiting. The damage is suffered first and foremost by companies, which lose revenues and market share, the State, in terms of lost tax revenue, and, last but not least, by citizens, who put health and safety at risk. It would therefore be important to understand whether the expert group set up by the Commission has stronger instruments than those of the OHIM Observatory for combating systemic infringements of intellectual property rights and, furthermore, what concrete actions it can promote or stimulate in the fight against counterfeiting offences by mafia or paramafious organisations.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! Combating infringements of intellectual property rights is particularly important for the cultural and creative industries. The European Union is a leader in industrial innovation, new design and a creative economy. In order for this to continue in the future, cooperation in the fight against infringements of intellectual property must continue and be intensified. That is why I fundamentally welcome the establishment by the Commission, announced by the Commission in the EU Action Plan on the Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights, of an expert group to enforce precisely these rights and the plans to further intensify work with the Observatory, with OHIM. However, it must also be pointed out here that the clear task of this new group of experts does not overlap with the experts involved in the Centre – here too, there are already corresponding expert groups. I would also like to take this opportunity to support the fact that the involvement of representatives of Parliament and the relevant committees, as well as the Centre, is extremely important. The European Union cannot afford to suffer from the sometimes massive infringements of intellectual property, as well as its cultural and creative industries and its large creative industries. It is therefore of enormous importance to exchange views with all the actors and also to bring the cultural and creative people to the table, including in this new group of experts. Structures should be created to make it easier for small and individual actors to enforce their rights. If the European Union is to remain at the forefront of innovation for new designs, technology and culture, better cooperation in combating intellectual property infringements at all levels is essential. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the My question relates to bilateral trade agreements. What opportunities do we see here to raise these points and also to assert European interests?

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I think it is very important that we exclude the agreements or agreements that we have concluded in Parliament, particularly with regard to the creative industries and cultural aspects, in the negotiations, for example on the TTIP international trade agreement, and make it clear that we want to have special consideration of our European specificities at this point. This should also be discussed in this body in an advisory capacity to the Commission, so that here too we take clearer and more account of the position of European creatives.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: Mr President, I too would like to thank the Committee on Legal Affairs for putting IPR enforcement on the agenda of this week’s plenary and to thank Commissioner Bieńkowska for her clear response on what the role of the expert group and the role of the Observatory will be.  To create a digital single market requires action on IPR enforcement, as consumers require complete trust in the goods which they are purchasing online and that they do not infringe IPR. If you consider that 39% of EU GDP, worth EUR 4.7 trillion annually, relates to IPR intensive industries, which account for 35% of all employment in the EU, those who commit IP crime deny revenue to national tax authorities, damage consumer trust and discourage entrepreneurs and SMEs from innovating and investing, particularly in the digital space. I welcome the Commission’s initiative and the proposed ten-point plan on IPR enforcement and the clarity on what the Commission’s expert group will do and what the Observatory does in this field. I am pleased that the Commission will allow MEPs to observe their expert group and hope that the MEPs chosen will reflect the range of committees in this House which share an interest in IPR enforcement.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, those who are still there! Today we are talking about the Commission's decision to set up an expert group on the enforcement of intellectual property rights. I would like to make two comments: we have a common internal market. That is a good thing, and it is important, and no one wants to shake it. But what we also have is an office for it: the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. The protection of intellectual property rights is already located there. So if the Commission is now setting up another group of experts, precisely on this subject, it is reminiscent of a popular game. On German, they say, "If you don't know any more, then set up a working group." It seems that one hand does not know what the other is doing. Or worse, one hand does not even know that the other exists. If this is not the case here, then I would like to raise the real problem that it is not so much the creation of double structures, which is obviously at stake here. I do not think we have all understood what the Commissioner has been dealing with here, why it is not a double structure. In any case, it didn't get to me. The problem is that if we want to increase citizens' support for the European Union, we should not create more working groups and offices, but abolish them. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I was really interested in your speech. I am a new person here, I was only elected in May, but the thing that I have noticed, and I wonder if you would agree, is that the main thing this place is really good at is creating new committees, new bureaucracy and new ways of shuffling paper rather than actually attending to some efficient business. Would you agree that that is the main strength of this place?

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, I would think that, in the sense of your question, this is certainly another important contribution to this. Further bodies will be set up. The citizens are wondering what they are for. This increases the frustration of the citizens of the European Union against them, and the Commissioner has just tried to explain to us what the difference is between the existing group, the existing office, and the newly created expert office or group of experts. If I were to ask now: who can define this? I do not think anyone can say exactly what the difference is between the newly created office and the existing office. In this respect, another frustration.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, We must also thank Mr Svoboda, Mr Cavada and Mr Dzhambazki for having opened this debate on intellectual property and its protection. What is happening is that the approach to the question ignores the real problem, because, in order to have a global debate, we should be talking about ensuring universal access to culture, infringement of the right to privacy on the Internet, freedom of expression — I have to say that in my country, Spain, websites can be closed without a warrant — or the lack of support for creators , while laws are being made to favour large distribution companies. Let us open a comprehensive debate that speaks of companies taking charge of the cost of the levy so that the creators are justly remunerated; let's discuss the entity responsible for defending copyright— which, in our view, should be a public entity that guarantees access to culture—and give a boost to alternative methods, such as Creative Commons licenses, so that authors can decide how they want to exploit their work.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the application of the rules protecting intellectual property is a fundamental aspect of the completion of the digital single market. In this respect, regardless of the specific tasks that will be assigned to the group of experts, I would like to make a general comment. I believe that the work and tasks of this group must be guided and inspired by respect for and protection of the freedoms and rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, as well as by national constitutions, of course. I say this with a view to what has happened, and unfortunately continues to happen, in Italy with AGCOM, the so-called independent administrative authority, which, in defiance of basic fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression and the right to news and defence, applies the regulation on the protection of copyright on electronic communications networks which it itself has issued in a sad manner. Fundamental rights and freedoms are a prerequisite for the protection of intellectual property and the completion of the digital single market.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen colleagues, intellectual property has been and will be one of the priorities of the European Union, the evolution of human society being based on creativity and inventiveness. Profile industries contribute around 38.6% to the European Union's domestic product, and the defence of these rights aims to promote people's ability to create concepts and values that lead to the economic development of society and the increase in the number of jobs. Europe itself is attractive to investors because of the legislative framework that preserves and promotes intellectual property rights. I welcome and encourage any steps taken at European Union level in this regard. However, I am of the opinion that possible overlaps of the Centre's responsibilities with those laid down by the expert group should be avoided. I support the establishment of a simplified functional framework by clearly establishing the tasks of the two entities for the efficiency of the business and the responsible use of human and material capital and, last but not least, for reducing unnecessary costs. I am convinced that both Parliament and the Commission will continue to support the progressive harmonisation of this sector.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: Mr President, first of all I will take 10 seconds from the beginning to share my colleague Manolis Glezos' anxiety about the tragedy that Greece is going through, about the need to support Greece, or else it will also be the anguish of Europe. I have the honour of being rapporteur for the Socialist Party (the President interrupts the speaker to remind him that he must stand up when he speaks) to the Committee on Culture on this important issue, namely intellectual property issues, especially at this time of economic crisis. I will not repeat what colleagues have said, but I admit that, while some of the answers have been satisfactory, they are still blurred on the following main issues – and so my concerns remain – : At what stage is this group of experts set up? What is the relevant timetable, if any? What are the criteria for selecting experts? Key questions! What are the scheduled meetings?  Finally, – and here there are questions – what will be the framework for cooperation between this expert group and the authorities of the Member States? Will there be full transparency?

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: Mr President, our laws enshrine private property as one of the fundamental pillars of our coexistence. This will be fine, but there are other rights that sometimes collide with this and, moreover, not all private properties are respected equally. In my country, for example, if a humble family cannot pay the mortgage, the private property of the bank is respected, and the family goes to the streets. However, if a large corporation wants to build a dam in a valley and recreate a swamp, entire villages are expropriated and nothing happens. With the information and knowledge economy, the same thing happens. Intellectual property may be a good general principle, but it cannot help prevent hepatitis C patients from receiving the medication they urgently need. It cannot serve to prevent visually impaired persons from accessing written works, in clear violation of the Marrakesh Treaty. The economy and the principles that underpin it must be at the service of people, not the other way around.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Mr President, indeed in 2012 the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights was established as a network of experts and stakeholders, and this Observatory was regulated by regulation. There was no doubt trying to protect intellectual property rights. The Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market was responsible for financing the activities of this Observatory. Now, as decided in September 2014, it seems that a group of experts will be set up in a complementary way – as the Commissioner has told us – with a political but complementary task; but the question is very timely in order to be able to call for the avoidance of duplication of functions, since public money is scarce and, therefore, we want to stress that there should be no duplication. The Observatory has the task of advising and assisting national authorities, raising awareness of this issue and, ultimately, their proper work. I conclude by saying that Spain effectively ratified the Marrakesh Treaty, which is very important for visually impaired people, although I understand that it has nothing to do with the subject at hand today.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: The European Commission has created this expert group. I wonder, however, why this group was still needed, if we already have a clear and precise action plan to protect the right to intellectual property. If we do have this team of experts, then I call on the Commission to use these specialists to speed up the implementation of the proposed solutions and to stop delaying concrete action.  Rather, we need a clear timetable for action. There are three clear directions in the field: informing consumers, supporting and protecting innovation, blocking the distribution of copied products. Without immediate action, European innovative companies are losing significant funds. Creative researchers are leaving Europe because their ideas are not protected or supported, as is the case with digital entrepreneurs, and citizens are fooled by products that often do not comply with consumer protection rules. Remember, when we talk about intellectual property, we are talking about a right, and I call on the European Commission not to seek other solutions when it should normally act directly.

name: Milan ZVER
text: I would like to thank my fellow Freedom party and the group proposing the creation of an expert commission which, together with the Observatory, will properly regulate this area. I want him to be a member of the Committee on Culture of the European Parliament. It is good that the European Commission wants to improve the enforcement of intellectual property rights. However, as my colleagues have already pointed out, I also want the various institutions within the European Commission not to duplicate their tasks, their work. The intellectual property group may not perform the same tasks as they are already performing. The issue of intellectual property is important, not least because it has a significant impact on the European Union's progress on the Digital Single Market, which can bring about 220 000 new jobs in the coming years. By properly protecting intellectual property, we can reduce the import of illegal products. However, we must be careful not to increase the bureaucratic burden on businesses. By protecting intellectual property rights, for example through patents, trademarks, we can ensure that companies, inventors and creators obtain adequate earnings for their intellectual work. But we must not forget that everything, or as much as possible, is created in society, which humanity creates, even accessible, on the other side, to the people.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make no further comments on the importance of protecting intellectual property for the competitiveness of our system. I also support and share this oral question, also because it underlines the need to make the actions to implement their strategies as coherent as possible. I would add that this coherence must also be ensured between the European Union's internal and external action, with the necessary senses that have already been mentioned during this debate. In July 2014, the Commission published its new intellectual property protection strategy in its relationship with third-party trading partners, on which the European Parliament is preparing its own-initiative report, which includes the protection of trade marks, patents and geographical indications. We therefore call on the Commission, in its response to this question, also to specify what instruments it intends to put in place to ensure that intellectual property is guaranteed not only in the internal market but also in its relationship with third-party partners.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this You have already heard it in many voices: it is about intellectual property, it is about copyright, it is an issue on which many companies have a lot of money involved. There are already really huge commercial interests. That is why, of course, it makes sense to take a closer look at this issue. It is a topic of the present and even more of a topic of the future. That is why it makes sense to set up a group of experts now. OHIM as an agency, of course, has very valuable tasks. However, these tasks need to be supplemented. And this group of experts is not a "l'art pour l'art" or an additional working group, but must clearly be given a task in its mandate. It is particularly important that the European Parliament should have a supervisory role, that it is possible to participate in the expert group on an equal footing, and so that the European Parliament can also carry out its checks-and-balances task. The whole thing makes sense.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, I too would like to join those who are calling for redoubled efforts in the fight against infringement of intellectual property rights. There are plenty of administrative duplications and what is lacking is efficiency, precisely to guarantee copyright. The culture sector is paramount to economic development and to the image of the European Union and its Member States; a sector that generates 6.5% of gross domestic product and a lot of employment. Clear regulatory frameworks are needed. The rights of authors and artists cannot be further devalued, in a way that is often contradictory to Community legislation. Clear frameworks are needed to prevent attacks such as those received in countries such as my own, Spain, which imposes an intellectual property law without dialogue, of dubious constitutionality and which certainly violates European legislation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, supporting the fight against infringements of intellectual property rights is an inescapable priority, especially in an interconnected society such as today's. It is easy to see a progressive reduction in privacy in communications, as well as in the exchange of digital information between consumers and database holders, data that are collected and used even without the knowledge of their rightful owners. I am therefore in favour of creating ever greater synergy with the activities carried out by this authority, provided that the criterion of efficiency and cost-effectiveness is maintained and respected. I am also in favour of parliament's possible participation in the activities, with the invitation of experts to meetings as observers to facilitate the exchange of best practices, and I am convinced of the need for all regulatory, technical and operational measures to be put in place by the data receiving authorities to ensure the protection of the confidential information in question.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is very important to protect the achievements of our creative minds across Europe. In this respect, I am in favour of strong copyright, patent and trademark protection and I think that setting up the expert group last year was a sensible idea. Now, however, we have noticed that the trademark office in Alicante is also taking on this task. We have a new Commission which has set itself the objective of cutting red tape and promoting lean structures, and I therefore believe that this dual structure that now exists can be dispensed with. The expert group is outdated. In the coming weeks and months, we in Parliament will continue to deal intensively with the question of how we, above all, develop copyright in this united Europe, also with regard to the digitisation of our lives, our value chains. We need to have the discussion here, not the expert group. In this respect, I believe that we can do without the expert group. A thank you to our chairman in the Committee on Legal Affairs who initiated this debate. I believe it is necessary to discuss this.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, the task force, the commission, which has been established by experts, we definitely need it. I do not accept the thesis that it is not necessary, because it is creativity, intellectual property, but unfortunately the patchwork is somewhat in the legislation, and especially in practice it is a European problem. We have a single market, but we don't have all the cleared intellectual property and we don't have all the copyrights cleared and protected.  That is why I want the legal part, and on the other hand the practice, to become unique in Europe because of our single market. The creativity of Europe and what we have in Europe has always been our, perhaps greatest, wealth. The creativity and intellect that our artists have, that our producers have, that our creators have is something that almost no one else in the world practically has. That's what Europe has built its economy on and I think it needs to continue to be built on that.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the issue we are discussing is really serious. But the answers we have received from the Commission are not clear and have probably complicated the issues. Intellectual property is a given that it contributes to the development of the economy, it supports the knowledge economy, which we all want to have in the European Union, it supports the digital market and of course it also supports investment in research. At the same time there is unfair competition from third countries, from different circles that violate intellectual property rights. Developments are certainly on the way and we need to keep a close eye on them so that they can take the initiatives they need. It is certain, however, that this area of intellectual property protection belongs first of all to the Member States and there must be coordination between the Member States. I think the expert group is gaining considerable power and limiting the powers of the Alicante Observatory. The European Parliament must also play an additional role.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Mr President, the protection of intellectual property rights and copyright is extremely important and I am glad that today we have the discussion here in Parliament. But we did not understand, Commissioner, and perhaps in the answers you tell us, did the expert group think or have you thought about having specific tools? Because it's one thing to protect an industrial drawing, a creation in industry, and another to protect a literary, film, music, theatre creation. We know very well that now, when we speak, there is a lot of piracy in the field of film, in the field of artistic creation, in music. These people have a cost and cannot recover, practically, their investment and, obviously, their work.  Have you thought about finding specific tools for each domain? And let us not forget, Commissioner, I have said it since the Commissioners' hearing: we need to regulate and also have trade defence measures within the European Union market; we often over-regulate indoors and leave the entry of products into the European Union market without any barriers.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your questions and remarks. We have listened very closely and carefully to them. It has to be said that the issue of the enforcement of IPR is only a part of the broader action of the Commission on the modernisation of the IPR framework at EU level. The question which should be answered first is that concerning duplication of group experts in the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). Ms Regner, I would like to thank you very much because you were very much to the point. First, the OHIM agency, according to the mandate, cannot advise the Commission. The agency is working on the current issues and cases. It is collecting data. We need to have a body consisting of the Member State experts to advise us for the future and on the next steps to take. It is much broader than just focusing, as the agency is doing, on the current ongoing cases and day-to-day work. It should also be said – for example to Mr Dzhambazki but many of you asked about it – that no new money has been dedicated to the activities of the expert group. Secondly, Mr Köster asked about the mandate. It is of course public and available online. This is a Commission decision. We can provide each one of you with the information if necessary. In responding to Ms Reda, of course the minutes are also public. There has been only one meeting of the expert group and the minutes have not yet been adopted. According to the mandate, they will of course be transparent and published as soon as the whole documentation provided by Member States and adopted by the group is available. Thank you very much for your remarks on the cultural sector. This is of course extremely important and will be discussed as a part of the digital single market. This is part of copyright reform. The Commission is very aware of the sensitivities of the copyright reform and IPR will be an important part of the digital single market strategy, while the discussion on copyright reform is of course in line with this. Regarding the concrete mechanism we will provide, the first thing is the copyright review and then we have to go through the IPR Enforcement Directive and look at why it is not working. It was approved in 2004. Then we will work on the trademark package and the trademarks and trade secrets. Let me remind you that there is ongoing legislative reform on the trademarks and trade secrets which will help companies better to protect their innovations. To conclude, after the few measures dealing with current issues, the expert group will advise us in what way we need to go further. Only two Member States have not appointed their experts to the expert group, not thirteen. Members of the European Parliament are invited to participate in the expert group meetings and we count on your expertise on this. In the coming months we will all be focused on the implementation of the ten-point action plan. The expert group was one of the points of the action plan.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement extending the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum (2015/2526(RSP)).

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, the Commission welcomes the initiative of the European Parliament to adopt a resolution on the renewal of the Internet Governance Forum. This also highlights many important aspects for the current global discussions on internet governance. This topic remains a priority for the European Commission. I look forward to working with you to further promote and improve the multi-stakeholder model for internet governance, which is such an important resource for Europe’s economy and society. Last year the Commission adopted its communication on internet governance and policy. The Council conclusions adopted in November will certainly help us to position ourselves in the global debate. The European Parliament and Commission have been working side by side on these issues, in particular in the context of the IGF. We wish to promote a unified internet based on the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Commission looks forward to continuing in these efforts with you. This parliamentary resolution is another step in this direction. It also comes at the right moment because 2015 will be a critical year for internet governance and there are important developments ahead. The text of the resolution rightly acknowledges this and reflects the importance and impact of the current discussions for the EU. Our main common objective is to make sure that the internet remains a truly global resource, free from being captured by a few or by specific economic or political interests. The internet is for everyone. We need a system built on cooperation, trust and the clear rules that can safeguard them. This is why a greater global balance should increase the legitimacy of the existing governance arrangements. As you know, the Commission welcomed last year’s decision of the United States Government to transfer key internet domain name functions to the multi-stakeholder community, known as the IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority) transition. An important ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers) meeting is now taking place in Singapore. I hope that there will be substantial progress made, including on the most sensitive issues such as those related to ICANN’s accountability. After all, ICANN cannot be itself the final judge in its own disputes with other parties. ICANN accountability and the IANA transition are closely interlinked. They are two sides of the same coin. The main challenge ahead is to ensure that the rights checks and balances are in place. At the same time we should stay focused on what is happening in the context of the review of the outcomes of the World Summit on the Information Society. As you know, the renewal of the IGF is at stake and it will be addressed in this context. I see some worrying signs coming from this process with constant pushes towards stronger multilateral approaches. On substance we must ensure that the World Summit on the Information Society will not lead to the introduction of stronger governmental control over the internet. We also support a stronger IGF, stronger financially, stronger in substance. This is essential to guarantee the stability that it needs to keep up with increased expectations from the international community. We also need other platforms to complement the current discussions on internet governance but without duplicating the existing efforts. Since the Commission supports the implementation of the NETmundial outcomes I am honoured to belong to the Coordination Council of the NETmundial initiative. I look forward to working with you to further promote and improve the multi-stakeholder model for internet governance.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome our Vice-President, Mr Ansip. Today we are discussing a resolution which will have the secure support — tomorrow - of the vast majority of the House and which has a very clear objective. There are many issues covered, but the main objective is to send a message so that the Internet Governance Forum can continue to develop its activity. The United Nations General Assembly will decide on this throughout 2015: will the mandate be renewed or not renewed? That's the point. In the opinion of the European Parliament, and on the basis of the experience we have had working side by side with the Commission, it is essential that it be renewed, because it expresses precisely that 'multipart' nature that internet governance must have. There is a threat that internet governance, internet governance, will be based on intergovernmental relations, rather than relying on stakeholder approach development or the multipart approach.  It is therefore essential that we give, from here, an unequivocal signal with resounding support; that the Commission and that the Council — and that each Member State, also individually — should be able to support this call to the United Nations to support the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Stakeholders from 144 countries attended the last Internet Governance Forum in Istanbul. The declared aim of this open forum is to inspire those who have decision-making power over the design and use of the Internet through discussions that have taken place there. The Forum is based on a mandate from the UN: it is intended to implement Article 19 of the Convention on Human Rights, the right to freedom of expression. The Forum lives solely on the power to be respected and respected worldwide. Internet governance, however, means more than just regulation, but takes a much more holistic approach. Current core problems have been identified: rights, freedom and access to information and user rights on the Internet. This year's World Economic Forum in Davos also addressed fundamental questions of the network. It is noteworthy that, among other things, company representatives concluded that some applications on the Internet can lead to an undesirable concentration of power and that there is an existential interest in connecting seven billion people worldwide equally. Both are demonstrably best achieved by providing good protection for net neutrality. In the United States, the signs of the times have clearly been recognised. Tom Wheeler, the head of the FCC, for strict net neutrality should also make us stand out in Europe. He wants to ban any paid preference, blocking or slowing down any content so strictly because the lax handling of it has brought competition in America to a standstill. Let us not fall for the rhetoric of local network operators who are now saying: 'We do not need this, competition is still working here'. Yes, it still works because we do not have the free play of the free forces here, because we have realised that the debate on special services is more than an economic one, and it is about prioritising fast lanes and restricting communicative freedom. That is why we need to use the platform of the Internet Governance Forum.

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, our internet must be open, yet safe; accessible, yet affordable; exciting, diverse and dynamic. We in Europe start from a great position: the World Economic Forum has listed the most technology-ready countries and the top three are all in Europe. But to unleash the potential we must earn trust. Consumers need to know that their rights are protected and their data is secure and treated responsibly. Creators need to know that their work, their IP, has value. Investors need to know that we politicians are not going to keep changing the rules that affect their investments. And businesses need to know that they have a level playing field where small companies are not unfairly blocked by the big ones and where new innovators are not blocked by the old. An open internet is essential but in safeguarding net neutrality we must take care not to inadvertently place barriers on future innovations. In safeguarding privacy we must not undermine the security of our societies or the safety of our children. In safeguarding data we need to make sure we do not place unworkable burdens on small businesses or lose the chance for society to benefit from the understanding from big data. And yes, we must care for fundamental rights, but we are also at a time when our fundamental safety is under great pressure. Yes, we need to take advice from security experts, safeguard our rights, but provide the means to guard our citizens’ safety. To deliver this vision we need a global approach, not a fortress Europe: working with a multitude of stakeholders, listening to consumers and to business, the public as well as public authorities. I hope the IGF will help this process and it will all be better because of our working together.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there is a debate which asks the question of whether the internet is becoming a human right, whether the internet is becoming a utility like water? If so, what are the rules and rights online?  What it is key to remember in that debate is that the internet is not national, or even European; it is global, and any rule on surveillance, on competition, needs to be thought about in a global context to prevent any fragmentation of the internet. This is why we, as Europeans, need to support and be actively involved in the Internet Governance Forum, as a debate at international level about the internet – its challenges as well as its opportunities – is essential.  On behalf of the Liberals, I have stressed in this resolution that the human rights and fundamental freedoms that we have offline should be protected online as well. This is often forgotten. State-controlled internet, but also mass surveillance and online censorship are on the rise around the world, including in Europe, and this clearly goes against our fundamental freedoms. My country, Estonia, ranked second on internet freedom. However, it was almost an exception as 84% of countries had, in 2014, weak laws or no laws at all to protect citizens from mass surveillance. It is getting worse, as it was 64% in 2013.  I would add one point to that. The rights of individuals to secure communication, including through encryption, are part of the same debate and this needs to be discussed as well in the Internet Governance Forum.  I strongly believe that the day the privacy of individuals on the internet ends will also be the day that the internet ceases to exist as an open platform of innovation and exchange of ideas. I therefore hope that the Commission will be active in promoting these values at international level.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The Internet thrives on an interesting contradiction. There is hardly anything that is more regulated. This is a computer system. Computer programs that have no nature, which consist only of artificial rules and guidelines that have been made by humans. At the same time, the Internet is an unregulated success story. It was designed openly and freely, open standards, everyone can/could do what he or she wanted in it. Only in this way could the Internet become the success story it is now. This freedom of artificial unregulatedness is threatened because interests have changed, because governments and corporations very often agree that stronger regulation, different regulation of the network, would give them greater benefits. It is a good place for the European Parliament to promote the Internet Governance Forum and to promote a free network that continues to promote and promote open regulation internationally, at international level, and to do more. I would like to single out two points in this resolution on which I am pleased that we will now have a broad majority in favour in this sitting. This is net neutrality and the issue of surveillance. A free Internet needs net neutrality, we agree. I hope that, if there will be other votes in the next few years, we will also find reasonably comparable definitions of net neutrality. Because everyone is for that, but whether everyone understands the same thing, I dare to doubt. In my view, net neutrality is something that cannot be downgraded, cannot be classified, should not be considered in a differentiated way, but that all data traffic should be treated equally. I hope we can agree on that. When it comes to surveillance, it is similar: everyone is in favour of protecting privacy, civil rights; the definition is often different. I hope that, as a Parliament in particular, we will position ourselves very strongly in this regard in the future and defend the rights and freedom of the population and, above all, the innocent and the unsuspecting in the case of mass surveillance, more strongly than the interests of the secret services. Finally, i.e. a call: if we as a Parliament take Internet regulation, the Governance Forum seriously, we should work for the widest possible delegation of Parliament there. An extension would be desirable.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, if there is a phrase which should put all of us on our guard, it is that of internet governance. Every politician who believes in freedom of thought, expression or religion, or in free enterprise, should feel a chill at the words ‘internet governance’.  The themes of the meetings of the IGF over recent years have been full of feel-good buzz words, but that is all they are. The existence and growth of the internet and its facilitation of the exchange of ideas horrifies established elites who are no longer able to control and manipulate information to their advantage. For them the internet is the greatest threat to the established order since the publication in the late Middle Ages of the Bible in the vernacular. Eternal vigilance is needed to ensure that governance is not merely a cover for state control. Plainly there should be the means of preventing the dissemination of, for example, child pornography, or material that facilitates terrorism. But every attempt to control freedoms and free enterprise should be fiercely resisted. Secondly, we must remember that the internet is largely the creation of free enterprise. When we hear anyone talking about how governments must act to promote or provide growth for the internet, we must never forget that governments are pretty much incapable of managing their own IT projects, and the notion of the governments being the driver of growth on the internet is illusory. The principal duty of the IGF should be to guard the freedom of the internet and to create the conditions in which free enterprise can flourish, not to introduce pettifogging regulations which clog its arteries. By all means have agreements on internet addresses and international standards for internet hardware, but leave ordinary human beings alone to promote the internet as a motor for freedom and growth.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: Mr President, the internet is now a formidable tool for economic, cultural, political and ideological promotion. This gigantic area of free expression is perhaps the only real democratic achievement of the last fifteen years. Indeed, in the face of the oligarchic and technocratic turning point that characterizes our time, the Internet allows the expression of the multiple currents of real society. It is a rather tasty paradox to note that the most dematerialized technology, and which defies distance, is the forum of new and entrenched opinions opposed to a liberal globalization. Of course, there is the unacceptable, such as the promotion of terrorism. However, let us keep false good solutions, because the closure of jihadist sites makes it even more difficult to detect terrorist activities and is easily circumvented by structured channels, while a permanent state of emergency is established to the detriment of all. The fight against the excesses of the internet should not be used as a pretext to limit the democratic freedoms of the greatest number. Avoiding plane crashes should not lead to the removal of aviation.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! 2015 will be a key factor in the development of new structures in Internet governance. The European Union must continue to participate intensively in these international debates. In the past, the IGF has provided a constructive and concrete framework for this international exchange with all stakeholders. This should continue to be ensured in the form of a continuation and an extension of the mandate of the IGF. It is particularly important to emphasise the importance of the multi-stakeholder approach in Internet governance in this context. It is essential to pursue this approach, as it is only in exchange with all stakeholders that sustainable solutions for the Internet and Governance can be found. The model of Internet governance by various stakeholders must therefore not be restricted. The intergovernmental approach, which is repeatedly called for by individual groups, is, I believe, the wrong way to go. It is therefore up to all Member States, as well as stakeholders, to further strengthen the sustainability of this model by improving the accountability of actors at regional, national and international level, so that the procedure can be made more transparent and inclusive, thereby ensuring real output for work on the ground. The internationalisation of the main functions and organisations of the Internet is of the utmost importance. The internationalisation of ICANN should therefore be pursued without being at the expense of trust and security. I would therefore like to emphasise in particular that ICANN's work should be fully accountable and transparent. The internationalisation of the IANA process, the high-priority IANA functions, should also be pursued. Here, too, I expect the European Commission, as a Parliament, to be actively involved, and also the approach of my colleague to send a stronger delegation to the next IGF.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Mr President, I very much welcome the fact that the European Parliament has once again taken the initiative in the key area of digital and internet technologies. I believe that 2015 will be a very important year not only in terms of extending the mandate of the IGF, but also in terms of transferring control of the Office for the Allocation of Internet Numbers to the international community, but also strengthening the influence of those independent initiatives or platforms such as the aforementioned NetMundial, which brings together very important internet actors. I, like a large and significant part of the community, consider it very important for the UN General Assembly to extend the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, because it is one of the key platforms for discussing such an important communication tool as the Internet, not only for communication between people, but also for the growing impact on our economy. The forum has come up with very important recommendations, I would like to mention two of them – these are competitive regulatory aspects for the internent, but also data security and user protection. From this point of view, in my opinion, its influence is very important and I am in support of extending it.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Mr President, I fully agree with the comments made so far: yes, we must renew the mandate of the IGF; and yes, we must continue the move towards more international governance of the technical framework of the internet and the many economic and other services that use it.  The digital single market will be and is at the heart of the future of the European economy. As the resolution says: growth related to the internet economy is forecast to be almost 11% in the EU, with a contribution to GDP expected to rise from 3.8% in 2010 to 5.7% in 2016. These numbers do not even take into account the positive indirect benefits of the digital single market on the rest of the physical world. The EU and this House must have a role in this discussion as we cannot leave the fundamental regulation of the digital single market in the hands of bodies beyond our control.  But I must also note that international governance of the internet is also a double-edged sword. Just as we are getting a stronger voice in its governance, so too are countries that have no respect for fundamental and human rights. The EU must continue to work to form a united front with like-minded countries against those which wish to abuse this and other forums to justify their censorship of freedom of expression, assembly and access to information for their citizens.  We must unite against any great firewalls and mass surveillance on the internet. We must accept today that full and free access to information and the right to share information are the only way that humanity can move forward.

name: Julia REDA
text: Mr President, the internet is global by nature. Although the Internet Governance Forum is not a decision-making body, it has become an important part of the global dialogue on internet governance. Yet much work remains to be done to ensure that everybody can participate in this dialogue in a meaningful way. Governments, civil society, the technical community and industry participate in the IGF. It is clear that some of those groups have to rely more than others on external support for their participation. The participation of civil society, particularly, must be actively supported by the European Union. Stable financing of the IGF is important to ensuring its political independence. This is all the more important considering that at the last IGF in Istanbul, local opposition groups complained that they were not included in the official programme and had to resort to organising an Internet Ungovernance Forum in parallel to make themselves heard.  In addition, parliamentary opposition is one group that is still missing at the IGF. Therefore the European Union must not only ensure that the IGF is adequately funded, but this Parliament must also allow all political groups to send representatives to the IGF to be fully represented at this forum.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Mr President, the internet, it is true, is a real space of freedom that must be preserved. However, after the revelations about the existence of large-scale Internet surveillance programmes by US intelligence agencies and the risks they pose, in terms of internal security and policy independence, particularly in the states of the European Union, the peoples of Europe expect a strong and unambiguous reaction from you. They will not be satisfied with a lukewarm renewal of the negotiating mandate on internet governance. You are telling us that this global governance of the internet is supposed to guarantee fundamental freedoms and human rights, to be more transparent and to organize the resources and functions of the internet for all, anywhere and at any time. You say you want to challenge the U.S. governance management, but what are your own objectives? What's bothering you? That European nations should be spied on in this way? That Europeans no longer have privacy? Or that it is, in fact, the United States that does it, and alone? We remain very suspicious of your objectives and very dubious about your willingness to face the imperial interests of the United States. And nothing in the motions for a resolution presented by the political groups reassures us: forums, exchanges, negotiations... Nothing that can make the American giants blink. So yes, we will have to redouble our efforts to ensure that the European Union exists in the global debate.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The Internet Governance Forum is today the most democratic structure in which there is a discussion about the future of the internet in general. It cooperates not only governments of states, but also representatives of business, representatives of interest groups, NGOs, citizens, various people. The discussion about the future of the internet today is most crucial in the face of all the challenges we face. The Internet is changing, evolving, the amount of time internet users spend using apps is increasing rapidly, and the use of web browsers is declining. Today, we use more mobile devices than computers or laptops. Increasingly, applications are being created, programs tailored to specific devices, and they often do not work with other types of devices. And all this together makes the internet more and more "silo". Unfortunately, the network is becoming less and less open, so we internet users are also threatened by this. It is therefore necessary to discuss how to keep the global internet open in the face of the technological changes that we are witnessing. It is therefore important that the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum is extended by the UN General Assembly.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! Internet governance is one of the most important global challenges, a historic challenge. As at the beginning of the 20th century, at the beginning of motorisation, we now need a generally accepted set of rules. That is why we need the IGF as a forum for discussion. Two basic decisions are of particular importance to me, and they cannot be highlighted often enough. First, the protection of privacy in the digital world: all people have the right to move freely from government surveillance, and personal data is the private property of their individuals. On the other hand, the question of how the Internet is organised: the Internet is a public, universally accessible medium – the principle of net neutrality must therefore be clearly and unambiguously fixed. In both cases, Parliament has taken important decisions. We also expect the Council to abandon its hesitant attitude at long last.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: Mr President, internet governance is a contradiction in terms because we should all want the global internet to remain open without unnecessary barriers, but for that to be the case decisions on many levels must be taken the right way and the multi-stakeholder model should be given more meaning in our times. We need EU leadership not to leave governance to Russia and China and other countries whose governments often seek to gain legitimacy at international forums like the IGF for their isolating, repressing and balkanising actions.  EU leadership should also ensure that net neutrality is guaranteed here and then globally, and we should work together with internet users, NGOs and global partners to make human rights and fundamental freedoms applicable online as they are offline. Together we can preserve and safeguard the open internet to allow its opportunities to benefit all of us now and in the future. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Blue card question. - Dear Fellow Member, He said that Russia wants to have some kind of balkanizing and controlling effect on the Internet in the world.
