Am I wrong to know that Edward Snowden, who revealed the us's activities that totally control the Internet, is currently in Russia because that is where he was granted asylum. And from there, by the way, he continues this exploratory activity. How can you reconcile this fact with what you just said?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – As our colleague probably knows, just because a whistleblower has revealed the abuse of power in the United States by the intelligence services, this does not justify the Kremlin’s repression of speech, journalists, whistleblowers and opposition figures, whether they speak out online or offline. Furthermore, Russia requires data storage in Russia, and thereby it undermines and harms the open internet as we know it, not only for Russian citizens but for internet users worldwide.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the internet must be an area of freedom, respectful of the right to information and freedom of expression, but it must also respect the right to be forgotten, which is a fundamental aspect of the right to privacy and personal data.  The right to be forgotten was enshrined on 13 May 2014 by a judgment of the European Court of Justice. It allows anyone harmed by information published on the internet to force the operator of the search engine concerned to remove it when a reasonable exposure period, in the order of several years, is exceeded. This decision is important, but insufficient. Google is trying to resist it: on 6 February 2015, it published a report that calls into question the right to be forgotten. That is why the forum on internet governance must take over from the Court.  In particular, there is an urgent need to clarify three points. First, the period of exposure at which information may be subject to the right to be forgotten; second, the balance to be struck between this right to be forgotten and the public's right to information; and thirdly, the possibility of giving the right to oblivion an extra-European dimension, which is particularly necessary in the face of the American version of Google.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We need fair play on the Internet, we need access to the Internet for everyone, we need to avoid discrimination on the Internet, we need to create trust on the Internet. In other words, data protection and the protection of intellectual property are essential. In order to contribute our European values, the Internet Governance Forum is a very important platform. This forum has done its job in the past. I therefore very much hope that the mandate for the Internet Governance Forum will be extended. And if it is extended, then we Europeans must also be a very strong voice, and then we must be heard. I would like to underline what my colleague Sabine Verheyen said, namely that a strong presence from the centre of Parliament, alongside the Commissioners responsible, is also important in the negotiations. I would like to take this opportunity to recall our own homework when we talk about the further development of the legal framework for the Internet, and I would ask the Vice-President of the Commission, also with regard to the General Data Protection Regulation, with regard to the telecoms package, to urge the Member States that progress is finally being made here, that we are making progress in the negotiations. , so that we in Europe can complete our homework quickly and then, with a strong position, also open up internationally.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the Internet is an inexhaustible resource of knowledge, a guarantee of widespread information, a source of new economic growth, a strategic instrument with geopolitical value, a new virtual agora that joins the historic squares of our cities. The growing importance of the Internet has not, however, been accompanied by adequate governance, which guarantees its transparency, democracy, security and neutrality. It is up to the Eu ropean Union to take a leading role in the world, making up for lost time, in order to make the network more inclusive and secure, without, however, compromising its freedoms and rights, which, on the web itself, can find new means of affirmation. Citizens must be able to have confidence in the digital environment in order to make full use of its new opportunities, such as e-commerce and the many services that the network can offer. Reaching agreement on the directive on the security of computer networks would be a first but significant step in this direction.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, through the governance of the Internet we have the opportunity to maintain this place, which is an open place, a strong place, a place where society has rediscovered itself to a large extent, and to leave space within the Internet to create value, to exploit the confidence that the Internet fosters, so that the Internet is also a place of development and not just a place of development. , as has often happened lately, a place of pitfalls, a place also of insecurity. Our task is to promote real governance. I do not agree with those who say – even during today's debate – that the concept of governance is incompatible with the concept of the Internet. I don't think so. Governance is not a protective and occlusive supervision, it is an area through which we try to make that space a space of opportunity for everyone. I am convinced of this. I am certainly convinced that we need to make progress. It is true that the IACC is still subject to Californian legislation today and, therefore, in a spacious environment such as the web, we cannot fail to imagine a development in this regard too, and you have anticipated it correctly and I thank you for that. I hope that this Parliament will maintain a position within the Internet governance forum and that this place, this web governance environment, will retain its role over time.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Mr President, I would like to support the renewal of the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum and the multi-party negotiating approach. But I want to draw attention to one aspect that I consider crucial: the need to ensure an open and independent internet. It is crucial to deepen efforts to ensure the legal protection of net neutrality as an indispensable condition for ensuring freedom of information and expression, and boosting growth and employment. In November, President Obama drew a clear red line by betting on the highest possible measures to protect neutrality. In recent days, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission proposed to prevent network access providers from discriminating against content or applications. Steps are taking place across the Atlantic; Europe cannot be left behind. Ensuring net neutrality and a free and open internet is essential to ensure one's freedom of expression on the network and its proven ability for pure innovative talent to generate activity and employment.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, Commissioner Ansip, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work I believe that Internet governance is the question of the future. That is why the LIBE Committee has also submitted a request to STOA to analyse the NSA surveillance activities accordingly technologically and to analyse what technological possibilities are available here. It has also been clearly stated here that not only can intelligence agencies take advantage of these means of surveillance, but that it can also be very quickly that terrorist organisations are also provided with the keys that make safe lines unsafe. That is why I think it is very important for us to define the protection of our devices first, because I want to be able to decide for myself what goes out and what goes into it on my device. We need a protective shield for our devices that absolutely ensures privacy. This really has a future. We want to prevent third parties from being able to do as they wish with our device in the future. That would be like someone from outside the Chamber being able to press my hand at will. And that cannot be the future. I believe that business and politics need secure lines on the Internet. Above all, our citizens must be safe, as is the case with the secrecy of letters. Ultimately, it is also a question of ensuring that network neutrality should not be abused by streaming services. I believe that the capacity used here in the future cannot be made available free of charge.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, the Internet is the vehicle to achieve the objective of the digital single market, the market which, according to estimates, will open the doors to 500 million potential consumers, which can increase the Union's gross domestic product by 4% over the next 10 years, i.e. by around EUR 500 billion. For this reason, the Internet needs to have as much institutional support and assurance as possible through a global agreement; safeguarding issues such as the security of citizens' personal data, such as the protection of our children, such as freedom of speech and the free movement of ideas. Support is needed on open issues, such as online neutrality, in order to maintain the competitive field for new innovative enterprises, which are the ones that can bring lost ingenuity in digital technology to European soil. Therefore, the Internet Governance Forum, since it first met in 2006 in Greece, has made a very positive contribution to dialogue and the exchange of best practices. It is an institution that strengthens effective policy-making with regard to the Internet, which is why I am in favour of the European Parliament renewing its mandate, not only because we should send a clear message to the United Nations but because we should, together and now, start taking the necessary steps to complete the single digital market so important to our economy by leaving the obstacles.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: We all, as well as business in Europe, are increasingly using the internet to do online trading both within the European Union and with the rest of the world.  The remarkable success of the internet is not just a coincidence. This is because the global network continues to develop every day as a result of the excellent functioning of its governance model. It allows interaction between all stakeholders, academia and citizens, NGOs, governments, large but also small companies.  The Internet Governance Forum has become a successful democratic platform for debate and exchange of good practices. I therefore fully support its continuation and further development. I call on the European Union and the Member States to support this proven approach to internet governance, given that in 2015 the UN will review its common IT policy. Taking advantage of the possibilities of the Internet, Europe can become a global leader in technology, supporting the open internet model. Finding a compromise on key issues such as roaming, copyright and net neutrality will allow us to seize the moment and achieve the completion of the Digital Single Market in the European Union.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, I am very glad that we have this proposal: after seven years we now have a resolution. I would like to thank Pilar del Castillo and her colleagues very much. This IGF – United Nations Forum gives a possibility for full debate also for the less-developed world. This is very important, to have them in. And I want to ask Mr Ansip whether the European Union cannot support non-governmental participation from the developing world: not only governments bringing their ideas, but having people engaged. Maybe I can get an answer in that direction. My second point is that I myself participated twice, in Vilnius and in Athens, and what I have seen there is that a lot of communication with all those partners and national parliaments is possible, and that is why I am a little sad about the fact that the parliamentary delegation has gone down and down. This is not the right signal; it is a bad signal to the internet community, and that is why we should put it on the agenda again. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the renewal of the mandate of the Forum on Internet Governance absolutely must be strongly supported by this Parliament. Since its inception in 2005, the Forum has had the great merit of fostering a transparent and multilateral debate on the governance of the Internet, also increasing the degree of cooperation between institutional and civil society stakeholders. The Internet is carving out an increasingly important role in our lives. In parallel with its development, however, there are a number of issues which must become a top priority for the European Union. I am thinking, for example, of the protection of minors on the web, the protection and promotion of freedom of expression, issues related to privacy and data security and the problem of the attribution of certain domains on the web, such as ".wine". I therefore believe that, precisely taking into account the whole interconnection of all these issues, it is the European Union's responsibility to support the Forum. The European Parliament delegations must therefore continue to promote European values through interaction with civil society organisations and representatives of the national parliaments present at the Forum, with the aim of ensuring that European citizens have an open, independent and secure network based on freedom of expression.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the Internet is known to contribute to the development of the economy, knowledge and, of course, to democracy. But the issues we have to deal with are important. What do we do about economic power issues, because monopolies have been created, have become dominant, often abuse this dominant position, control technologies, control research, violate individual rights. The second issue is also the role of states. Authoritarian governments block Access to the Internet, restrict freedom of expression, violate democratic rights, monitor citizens themselves. So we have to take serious action. Hit the criminal activity that takes place through the Internet. To protect the insult of personality. That is why the governance model must be open, pluralistic, participatory, with civil society and universities, safe and protect personal data. I therefore support the renewal of the mandate for the forum to be given by our Parliament.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we need this special forum, the Internet Governance Forum, and we need an extension of the mandate, not just for a year. We are committed to getting this forum a longer mandate, because we think it is a more correct and efficient way of working this forum. What I want to emphasize is all the principles we've heard here today, freedom, human rights, everything the internet carries.  But the Internet today is no longer just a product or service. The Internet is life. Today we spend hours and hours with the Internet. Unfortunately less with loved ones, more with the Internet. Unfortunately less in nice spaces, more with the Internet. That is why I said for the last time, we need a new philosophy around the Internet and I propose that the fifth freedom of the European Union be seriously discussed, about the digital freedom of the European Union that will induse all the principles we talked about, but also all the dangers that the Internet carries.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, the internet’s great strength is the freeing of information to all. You can access more information now through a small hand-held, relatively cheap device than in the greatest of libraries in the past. So no surprise then that politicians seek to control and to govern this, because knowledge is power, and knowledge is freedom. Yes, we must guard against abuses and, yes, we must never allow crime to thrive through the internet, but we must also make sure that politicians never control the net. Controlling knowledge means that the status quo is maintained. I say, let the information and knowledge flow free. Let the people know the truth and let us have an information and knowledge-inspired democratic revolution where freedom of speech and true democratic democracy come back to all of Europe. That would be a great day.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Mr President, I rarely find such great understanding and agreement here, across the political spectrum. It shows the importance of the European Community. If we can agree in this way, then we can indeed be a strong, decisive player in this international debate on such a fundamental subject, and that is, of course, if the mandate of the World Internet Governance Forum is extended, as we all support here. I hope and wish that our representatives support the principles that you have all mentioned here, in particular the principle of openness, the principle of equal access, the principle of the European digital single market and net neutrality. And I would also like to stress that the security and protection of intellectual property, copyright and protection against abuse are coming to the fore. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that our representatives will defend these principles.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: (the beginning of the speech is not called)... Free, collectively managed, secure Internet that protects users, but also digital developers, without affecting the right to privacy or protecting those who commit crimes. The European Union must become a leader in this field and strongly express its position for the continuation of the mandate given by the United Nations to the Forum for Internet Governance. We need involvement in the internet management of all actors and we need to fight against trends in controlling this space, such as ACTA, or what has happened recently in several European countries, including Hungary. But we need to create mechanisms by which institutions created to protect us can act. But we must understand that the internet means for many hopes. Hope for democracy in undemocratic states, the chance to develop a transnational business for small European entrepreneurs or the only way of communication for those who have their families away, such as the diaspora and the case of the diaspora in my country, Romania. (Applause)

name: József NAGY
text: Growth linked to the Internet economy is projected to be almost 11% in the European Union. The contribution to GDP will increase to 5.7% over the last five years. For example, small and medium-sized enterprises that make intensive use of the Internet are developing at almost twice the rate compared to other SMEs. The Internet has now become an important part of our economy at all levels and should therefore be supported. However, unconditional freedom is also taken advantage of by outlaws. This is how terrorist sites, forums, or even child pornography are generated on the Internet. Thus, in addition to supporting the independence of the Internet, I must mention that we must also place greater emphasis on safety, control of unwanted content and consumer protection.

name: Michał BONI
text: Mr President, I wish to make four points. Firstly, we need to review the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum, and I would thank Pilar del Castillo for this initiative. Secondly, it is important because we are at the front of the new fight on essential values for the internet: freedom, net neutrality, privacy and security. We do not want balkanisation of the internet, and a multi-stakeholder model of governance of the internet is the only guarantee for keeping those values.  Thirdly, the multi-stakeholder model of internal governance is the best platform for global discussion on the balance between freedom, privacy, economic development and security, with full respect to all dimensions of those problems. Fourthly, in Europe we need a much stronger network among national fora of internet governance.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Let's get to the point. I would like to ask the Commissioner responsible how the surveillance of internet traffic by european people is now? Because my great fellow Member listed here what outlaws can use the Internet. Such outlaws, for example, are secret services that, in the face of all human rights principles and rules in the United States, and in the context of the so-called "five-eye operation", the United States, England and the other three countries together, have monitored the entire internet traffic of European citizens, including their correspondence. In this regard, a report was adopted by the European Parliament almost a year ago. Please inform Parliament, Commissioner, of the state of the situation. Is the United States still monitoring and, with it, Britain's secret service illegally monitoring the internet traffic and correspondence of European citizens. This is an interesting and important question.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to cordially thank you for this fruitful debate. Many issues raised today are the focus of the Commission’s work on the DSM. The Commission is a strong supporter of the multi-stakeholder model for internet governance. It is also thanks to the involvement of the multi-stakeholder community that the internet, with its transnational and multidimensional nature, has been able to flourish and bring about innovation with all the benefits of the digital revolution. The IGF has successfully brought together different stakeholders for open and frank discussions. Even if much more can – and should – be done to improve this forum further, it has proved very helpful and valuable. As you know, the Commission has been one of the most stable and committed financial contributors to the IGF. This is vital for the stability that an organisation needs to function properly. To conclude, the Commission very much appreciates your work in this area. Genuine progress is necessary on internet governance so that there are structures that are inclusive, transparent, accountable and technically sound. Otherwise the risk is that more intergovernmental approaches will gain momentum.  The multi-stakeholder governance of the internet needs to be strengthened. It needs to be credible and inclusive. This is where the European Union, with its strong values of respect for human rights, diversity and the rule of law, can show its international leadership. We can and should be up to the task.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Mr President, I wonder whether the Commissioner should not answer some questions by Members of this Parliament. The Commissioner obviously wrote this – or it was written by somebody, I do not know whom – but somebody wrote this exposé. The first half of it was read beforehand, the second half after the so-called debate. This is not why we are here. As a Member of this Parliament and an elected politician I want your answer to my question.

name: Olli REHN
text: I have to say that this is not Question Time with the Commission and the Commission also has its freedom of expression. So we will continue. I have received four motions for resolutions. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 11 March 2008. The rapporteur was Mr S. President, Mr S. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – Renewing the mandate of the Internet Governance Forum is essential in order to guarantee multi-player participation in the adoption of Internet-related rules as one of the most important forums for internet governance. Member States should avoid agreeing exclusively with each other on the exclusive management of the Internet by means of an intergovernmental agreement and excluding business operators, experts and NGOs, and this agreement should include elements which are dexacing to freedom of expression, democracy and fundamental human values, as well as to the ability to renew the Internet and to continuously promote sustainable economic development. In order to ensure as much transparency as possible, it is necessary to channel the discourse within the framework of the UN-mandated IGF. As has now become clear, the Internet has a huge role to play in the recovery of the economy. I therefore support the adoption in the motion for a resolution on the IGF that the protection of internet neutrality is an essential precondition for freedom of expression and information flows and for the exploitation of growth, jobs, innovation and business opportunities.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – It is essential to renew the mandate of the Global Internet Forum (FGI), as a platform for monitoring, debating and self-regulating the use of the Internet. It is wrong to think that non-regulation guarantees the neutrality of the Internet. However, ensuring internet neutrality cannot call into question the area of freedom, creativity and value creation in which the Internet has become. Therefore a shared and open Governance is one that serves a healthy dynamic of internet development, justifying the renewal and strengthening of the FGI.

name: Olli REHN
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Giovanni La Via, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the indication of the country of origin of meat used as an ingredient in processed foodstuffs (O-000091/2014 - B8-0101/2015) (2014/2875)(RSP)).

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Chairman of the ENVI Committee. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, according to Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the measure of information on food for consumers, in December 2013 the European Commission published its report on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for meat used as an ingredient, accompanied by a working document on consumer attitudes towards the origin labelling of meat used as an ingredient, on the feasibility of possible scenarios relating to such labelling and on their impacts. The resolution adopted by the ENVI Committee proposes that Parliament should make a contribution to the indication of the origin of meat in processed foods, which could be useful in view of future legislative proposals by the European Commission. The Reports of the European Commission to which I referred a moment ago, as well as some surveys made in recent months, recognise that more than 90% of the consumers surveyed consider it important that the label of processed food indicates the origin of meat, thus demonstrating the strong interest of consumers in this information, which is one of the factors that can influence their behaviour. This is all the more true when we consider that, at Member State level, it is estimated that between 30 and 50% of the total volume of slaughtered meat is processed into meat for use as an ingredient for food, mainly minced meat, meat preparation and meat products. Commissioner, today we must regain the confidence of European consumers who, even in the wake of the recent food scandals, including the fraudulent replacement of beef by horsemeat, want stricter rules on traceability and information. Of course, these rules will not in themselves prevent food fraud, but they will also enable the authorities to carry out more effective investigations as well as inform consumers. The resolution does not forget the role of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are central to our economy in terms of creating growth, employment and development, and the commitment to quality and safe food. I therefore believe that a balanced approach between the different positions and interests involved is the way forward with a view to preparing new legislation in this area, which will have to take into account the transparency and legibility of information for consumers, while at the same time allowing European companies to operate in an economically viable and competitive manner, under conditions acceptable to consumers' purchasing power. On a specific point, we would like to ask the Commission for more information, namely on the assessment of the possible effects on prices of this measure. In fact, the results of research carried out by a consumer association French differ considerably from the data contained in the European Commission's report on the costs of introducing the indication of the country of origin on the label. I would therefore ask the Commissioner to look more closely at this issue in order to get a more framework. This assessment must not, however, extend the time when the legislative proposal is presented. When the Commission publishes its proposal, we will clearly react on the substance, together with the Council, on the basis of our prerogatives as co-legislators, but we are ready to make our contribution now through the work done on this motion for a resolution which contains our suggestions and the list of our priorities. We need clear, coherent and harmonised rules. We have a lot to do in the coming years and this is a sensitive area for our citizens. We therefore offer today and with wednesday's vote a positive and precise contribution to the European Commission, to which we are asking for legislative proposals to make it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods. We believe that information on origin, which is currently provided on a voluntary basis, may mislead consumers and that compulsory information can instead ensure greater transparency along the food chain and better inform European consumers. Finally, we call for impact assessments to be taken into account at the same time, avoiding excessive costs and administrative burdens for businesses. As I said at the beginning, our aim must be to regain the confidence of European consumers, reassuring them about the quality and safety of the food produced in our territory and offering them the information required in order to make a conscious purchase.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, consumer sensitivity about the origins of the foods they eat has certainly grown over recent years. Consequently, origin has become of increasing relevance for businesses and also for policy-makers. Before turning to the honourable Members’ questions, allow me to say a few words about the Commission’s report on the issue. The main purpose of the report is to set out in a neutral and objective manner all relevant factors in order to launch an informed discussion with Parliament and the Council. The report relies principally on the external study, which also includes a consumer survey. The coverage of the report is broad and heterogeneous. It covers all pre-packed foods with meat ingredients of all species. Products can range from relatively simple meat preparations, such as fresh meat with spices, to more processed meat-related products such as pizza bolognese. The supply chains of such products can also be quite complex and lengthy. Given the broad scope of the report, any estimated impacts must inevitably be both general and varied. Turning to the oral question, on the first point I would like to clarify that the Commission has not yet decided on any follow-up action. The report itself does not suppose or imply any a priori position of the Commission on the subject. The honourable Member’s second point cites a consumer study alleging that the cost-of-origin labelling of meat in processed foods is lower than price increases identified in the report. Here I should point out that the Commission report was based on estimates from the food industry. These estimates, as well as the methodology used, were discussed and endorsed in the context of a focus group comprised of professionals active in the food chain, including consumer associations. The figures provided in the Commission’s report take into account meat of all species and all structures of food supply chains across Europe. By contrast, the study mentioned by the honourable Member relates solely to beef products in France. For beef, origin labelling is expected to have the lowest impact, notably because of the existing traceability system and relatively lower volumes of intra-EU trade in bovine beef animals and beef compared to the other species. In the case of France especially, there is a sufficient supply of domestic raw material for the production of processed beef products. These estimated increases of 15%-20%, and up to 50%, mentioned in the Commission report refer to the additional operating costs for the industry and not the final product price, as is the case in the French study. These estimates correspond to the specific scenario where the indication of origin would be set at the Member State / third country level. The additional cost to the industry for origin labelling set at the EU / non-EU level ranges from negligible to up to around 25%. I would also like to note that it would be difficult to establish the final product price. In particular, depending on the strength of retailers or the suppliers, some of the cost increase might be absorbed downstream in the food supply chain, to the detriment of suppliers, and only partially passed on to the final consumer. Furthermore, the French study cited by the honourable Member does not specify the level of origin indicated on the label. It is therefore impossible to compare the estimates provided by these two sources. Finally, the French study summarised costs relating to origin indications provided on a voluntary basis. The estimations of price increases for voluntary schemes are less significant as they tend to cover cases where origin indication is feasible with relatively low cost. By contrast, mandatory origin labelling refers to all case scenarios, including those where it would be operationally difficult and costly. Therefore the costs are higher. As regards the third point on consumer preference, as to the level of the origin indication the Commission report fully reflects the observations pointed out by the honourable Member. According to the report, an origin indication set at EU / non-EU level may be considered from the consumer’s perspective as too generic and not worthy of any resulting price increase. However, at the same time, the report stresses the paradox of a discrepancy between consumer interest in origin labelling and their willingness to pay for that information. Mandatory origin labelling may negatively affect the consumption of needs-related foods. It is observed that consumers currently buy meat with origin indication less often than they would have wished, because of the price consideration. The price sensitivity is mainly reflected for origin labelling on meat used as an ingredient. The consumer would be interested in receiving the information at the highest level of detail possible if this information were to be offered without any price increase. Turning to the last point on the voluntary labelling of the origin of meat in processed food, let me reassure the honourable Member that such a system has also been addressed in the Commission’s report. The external study which forms the basis of the report looked into existing private schemes approved at national or concentrated industrial level. The study concluded that the use of such voluntary schemes concerning the origin of meat ingredients in meat-based products is generally limited. Where such schemes exist, they tend to be mostly private and not related only to geographical origin labelling, but rather form part of a wider quality initiative.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the As the Commissioner has just said, the consumer only wants this origin marking of meat in processed products if he does not have to pay extra for it. Three quarters of consumers say that if it costs something, if the product becomes more expensive, then I do not want it at all. That is why I do not understand why there are so many Members of this House who insist that it is essential that this origin marking should be in place. The consumer doesn't really want it. And the product will be more expensive, yes, definitely! That, too, has been pointed out by the Commissioner. Manufacturers have to take much more costs into account. Operating costs increase by up to 50%. In addition, we will have an increase in bureaucracy costs – plus 30% – and we are working against excessive bureaucracy. In addition, manufacturers need separate storage spaces and they need to design a lot of new labels and packaging. Because a slice of sausage is easily loaded with origins from four to five different countries. So they have to design 400 to 500 different labels and therefore packaging. Who is to handle this? The consumer does not want it, it costs a lot of money, it increases the proportion of bureaucracy, and there is absolutely no link between the horsemeat scandal and origin labelling. This is something that this Parliament, with the participation of all the groups that are now so in favour of this nonsensical, really stupid origin marking of meat in processed products, has clearly stated this. Finally, it has to be said that this origin marking is antisocial, because many people cannot afford to pay much more money for their food, and that would be the case. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the The previous speaker, Mrs Sommer, has actually qualified or not qualified by the fact that anything that obviously contributes to product safety is stupid and nonsensical for her. Mrs Sommer, may I ask you: do you know that everything but food has become more expensive? Food that may have cost 100% 100% 10 to 15 years ago now costs only 50% of the historical value. I ask you, if you know this, how can you insist that obviously the horror scenario that everything has to become more expensive is a God-given law? Can you not imagine that it is also in the interests of consumers that food should also be allowed to have a certain quality? That costs a certain price. Perhaps it will also benefit the farmers.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "I would also like to ask Mrs Sommer my question. I'm also a consumer, not just a politician. I have come to see many times products where not only the meat components, but everything, to the last angle, is beautifully indicated – and these foods are not more expensive than others, by the way. However, where goods of unsustainable origin are processed into meat products, it would obviously entail additional costs if they had to confess or be replaced with quality meat. Am I afraid of Mrs Sommer – and I ask this – are you really protecting food-toy farmers from normal producers?

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Answer to two questions about the "blue card" procedure. – For the origin marking of ingredients, meat as an ingredient: ingredients do not have to be labelled with the origin at all. This is the answer to the question put by the S&D colleague. Mr Product Safety, mr. from the right wing, has absolutely nothing to do with the fact that there is an indication of origin. We have European laws on food safety, hygienic quality, labelling, etc., which apply equally throughout all Member States. It is important that we have good control at home and that violations of the law are punished. This is the responsibility of the Member States. Origin marking has absolutely nothing to do with quality. On the contrary, it is protectionist. That's just coming from the right wing! I find it shameful that the left wing is taking part in this.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is several years since the Food Information Regulation was agreed. From the vote in Parliament at the time, it was clear that MEPs wanted country-of-origin labelling for all meat, including meat in processed foods. And although in the negotiations we finally agreed on origin labelling for fresh meat, MEPs and Member States were subjected to a huge lobbying campaign from industry. In the end, unfortunately, we could not get agreement from the Council on meat in processed foods. But of course, consumer groups were at a massive disadvantage, because they just cannot compete with the lobbying resources available to industry. The Commission report states that the costs will increase if we have country-of-origin labelling. However, the Commission’s report was based totally on industry self-reporting. So what did you expect? Consumer organisations were invited to the focus groups, but it is clear to me they did not and do not endorse the report’s findings. Consumer research from France found that labelling the meat in a frozen lasagne cost just 1.5 euro cents, and for a Bolognese sauce it would be less than a cent. Hardly that expensive, I think. And you know, if they really thought about it, this could be really good for the food industry, helping to restore the trust in their supply chain that has been so badly damaged in recent years due to the horsemeat scandal. What is really important is that over 90% of consumers say they want to know where the meat in the processed food they buy comes from. All we want is clear, honest food labelling. Surely consumers should not be misled. If a beef lasagne is labelled as a British product, that should mean it is made with British beef, and if it is labelled as a French product, it should be made with beef from France. It is not that difficult to understand. This Parliament led the way on labelling of nutritional information, on labelling of palm oil, on labelling of allergens to enable consumers to make informed choices about the food that they give to their families. This week we must send a clear, strong message to the Commission to bring forward proposals for mandatory country-of-origin labelling of meat in processed food. It is clearly what Parliament wants; it is clearly what the farmers want and, more importantly, it is clearly what consumers want. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Honourable Member, although I know that this subject is not black and white, I would like to ask you whether you are really so convinced that you will only increase the quality of the meat by proof of the origin of the meat in the food in question, in the product concerned. Therefore, by marking the origin of this meat, you will automatically increase the quality of this food. And then I would like to ask you whether you have actually received specific requests from specific citizens that we here approve the origin labelling of meat in a given product.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. It is not just about quality. Many people want to know where their meat comes from, for a whole range of reasons. It might be for environmental reasons, it might be the air miles that are travelled, it might be about the way the meat is produced – the standards of husbandry. If I buy a chicken sandwich and it says ‘produced in Britain’ I expect to know whether the chicken is from Britain or Thailand. People have a right to know that. And, yes, I get lots of people telling me they want this legislation. Ninety per cent of consumers is a large, significant number.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! The European Parliament has been debating for years whether processed meat should be labelled with country of origin so that consumers can see where the meat comes from. A study carried out by the Commission shows that at least 90% of consumers think that the labelling of processed meat is important, and I think that is also important.  This proposal is about trust between consumers and producers. In this context, we can say that the horsemeat scandal also made it clear that there is a real need to have a full overview of where the processed meat comes from.  Traceability, so that one can follow a product from farm to fork, is a consumer requirement that one should always meet. It is the right of consumers to know the whole origin, and therefore also the country of origin, of the food they buy. Of course, country-of-origin labelling requirements will never be able to prevent the fraud that has taken place, but it is part of a chain of requirements to ensure that consumers get the goods they pay for – and the culprits they must be punished if they cheat!  When processed meat is used as an ingredient in a product, it must of course be possible to find information on, for example, the country of origin of what you have purchased. A secondary effect of country-of-origin labelling may also be that countries will strive even more to meet the high consumer requirements and good animal welfare, as well as quality, and that those countries that may have a smaller one – what to say – are less good at meeting what they will be punished.  Just as a consumer would like to know where a whole chicken or pig comes from, you would of course also like to know where the processed meat comes from. It must therefore also be the case that you know the country of origin of the piece of bacon or the pâté or sausage that is being sold. In addition to the food safety that lies in seeing where one's products come from, then this proposal can also help to provide added value to food producers. Consumers want a little story about food.  (The Speaker agrees to answer two blue card questions in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Are you aware that the regulation on informing consumers about food requires that the origin must be indicated if the consumer is otherwise misled? In other words, if the product gives the impression that it is coming from somewhere else than it really does, then the origin must be indicated. Are you even aware of this? Secondly, you have given the horsemeat scandal as the reason for this origin marking, which we are discussing today. Are you aware that horsemeat was declared beef and that beef has been a source label for many years?

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Blue card question. Mr President! I would just like to say that I fully agree with what Jørn Dohrmann has said, but I would like to know whether he is also in favour of compulsory labelling? For the only amendments in the motion for a resolution tabled by his group, they are calling for voluntary arrangements, and one of the amendments even demands that it be completely gone! So it is only to know whether Mr Tsipras is a mr Saunders. Dohrmann speaks on behalf of his entire group, or only on behalf of a small part of it.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Blue-card response. Mr President! We want consumers to be informed of where the meat comes from. It must be the case that consumers feel safe when shopping for the family. And it is clear that when you have experienced a horsemeat scandal, well, it shows that there will never be 100% safety. Of course, when people want to swindle, they can do it! No matter how much we feel the meat all around, we can never avoid some people being swindling. But it is clear that those who are fraudsters must of course also be punished for it. They shouldn't just be able to walk around freely when something like this happens. But labelling is a guarantee to consumers and an information to consumers, and that is what I think we owe them.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, this is a question of Parliament's Committee on the Environment proposing that the Commission examine the effects of writing the origin marking of meat. Does it have cost implications and what kind, and what other effects does it have?  Studies show that a large proportion of consumers want to know the origin of meat. Not all of them, but very many people want to know how far the chicken or other meat has travelled before it comes to the plate. Estimates of these costs have been presented here, as well as in the Commission's papers. Here came the estimate that the price of a kilogram of meat would increase by 50% if the origin marking were to come. On the other, it is considered that it would be less than one centimetre per kilogram of meat.  If the fork is this large, then I think it really makes sense for Parliament to agree that the Commission should examine these cost implications. Surely no one wants compulsory labelling if the price of meat rises by 50%. But I can't believe that argument myself, and here I can appeal to Finnish experiences. We have food companies, companies that mark origin and very precisely. And that is not a price issue, at least not according to the own calculations of these companies. It will increase confidence in consumers, and this may also lead to an increase in meat consumption.  But this is not the main thing, but the main thing is that the consumer has a right to know what he is putting in his mouth. It is therefore important that the Commission should now be given the opportunity to examine the economic and other effects of both voluntary and compulsory designations of origin.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. –  Mr President, it is almost exactly two years after the horsemeat scandal exploded across Europe, and we are still calling on the slumbering Commission to wake up and propose legislation for origin labelling for all meat, including meat as an ingredient. The horsemeat scandal was the biggest food fraud of the 21st century, and it exposed the lengthy, complex, and often very murky extremes of food chains in Europe. That some of the biggest supermarkets were able to just apologise, and claim they didn’t know where the meat came from, is astounding. Whilst this scandal was – as rightly pointed out – caused by criminal activity, it underlined the extremely poor levels of traceability in the food chain, for consumers to know where their food is coming from. Ninety percent of consumers want to know the origin of their meat, both fresh and processed. This is a demand which has pre-dated the horsemeat scandal, and it still goes unfulfilled. The European Commission needs to stop being apologists for the corporate food industry and start acting to defend and represent the interests of the citizens that they supposedly work for. It would do well to avoid bleating out the big food industries’ arguments against and seek to implement as soon as possible what citizens and consumer groups have been calling for for years. The Commission claims, in its 2013 report – we have heard it here – that the production costs could increase by anything up to 50%. We know that the consumer groups have shown that the opposite is true. Let us not forget that, when it was introducing country-of-origin labelling for meat – unprocessed meat – we heard these same arguments. In Ireland, our voluntary labelling scheme, which includes meat and processed meals, has been a remarkable success, with almost 40 000 producers and 122 processors currently involved; this is a perfect example of the appeal and benefit to businesses such labelling can have. In fact, it is so successful that now what we have, because of the absence of mandatory labelling, is dishonest food manufacturers giving misleading representations of where the food comes from, labelling them as Irish recipes, traditional, farmhouse and local. So the European Commission needs to stop sticking its head in the sand and start listening to what consumers want.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as of April next year, EU consumers will know, when buying a pig cutlet or a chicken fillet, where the animal was reared and slaughtered. However, if they bought a pork pie or a chicken nugget, they would not have a clue as to the origin of their meat. Today’s proposal will bring a consistency with the new rules on country-of-origin labelling of unprocessed as well as processed meat. The 2013 horsemeat scandal not only shattered public trust, it reinforced consumers’ demands for information on how and where food is produced. Whilst no silver bullet against fraud, compulsory labelling of meat in processed foods would oblige food makers to keep a tighter grip on their suppliers and would make them more accountable for what they put into their food products. Research, as we have heard from the Commission and consumer organisations across the EU, consistently tells us that 90% of Europeans do care about the origin of their meat. They want to find this information on the label, whether the meat is fresh or used as an ingredient. The beef labelling model, whereby the animal’s country of birth, rearing and slaughter must be given, has raised consumers’ expectations, and people want to know the animal’s full journey from farm to table, because a more transparent meat supply chain will benefit not only consumers and businesses alike but make it harder for less scrupulous operators to cut corners. Some industry groups report that price increases of 15 to 50% would be triggered by mandatory labelling. Firstly, these increases are seen as scaremongering by some consumer organisations, and secondly, most people do not conceive of having to pay for knowing such basic information as the origin of the food on their plate. Colleagues, we have the opportunity to improve our food chain and make it more transparent. The public wants it, and we should believe that we should act in the public’s interest. Please support the Commission’s call to come forward with legislation.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our movement has always defended consumers and their right to know where the meat they consume comes from – as Mrs Willmott has explained very well before – for environmental reasons, for example. At present, there is no obligation at European level to indicate the origin of meat in processed products. This obligation exists only for meat when it is sold individually. Therefore, to date, every producer can freely decide whether or not to indicate the origin of processed meat and, if he decides to do so, he can do so without being obliged to follow any rules. This is absurd. That is why many producers point to the country of origin of only one of the ingredients of the final product – of course the country that suits them best commercially – or they freely choose to indicate only the ultimate country of food processing, while still benefiting from the marketing advantage that comes with it. This type of labelling is, of course, of no use, it only serves to make unfair competition between companies. In this way you can sell a product as if it were Italian, as if it were Spanish, as if it were Greek or English, etc., even if the meat it contains comes from a different country. Commissioner, you spoke earlier about voluntary labelling as a possibility. That is why, in the resolution, we called on the Commission to lay down clear rules for producers who decide to use voluntary labelling, but above all we have asked for clear rules to be laid down for those who decide not to label. From our point of view, the traceability of a product is an added value to the product and if a company decides not to label at that point it must in no way refer to the origin of any of the ingredients of its product because, otherwise, consumers will be misled. This is the only position that allows us to safeguard the freedom of choice of companies on the one hand and at the same time protect consumers from fraud. That is why, pending the compulsory labelling that we want, we have asked for our position to be adopted by means of an implementing act so that we can adopt these measures much more quickly than directives or regulations. (The speaker agreed to answer two blue card questions (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mr Pedicini, you quite rightly mentioned in your speech that the origin could be confusing, since it is sometimes the place of the last transformation. Even if the meat comes from another part of the world, if the last processing takes place in one country, it is said that the meat comes from the country in which the last processing took place. So for clarity, would you agree with labelling equivalent to that of fresh beef, which stipulates both the place of birth, rearing and slaughter of cattle?

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Pedicini, are you aware that the regulation on informing consumers about food contains a whole article in which everything possible is written against misleading the consumer by means of food labelling? It would therefore be a criminal offence if someone were to lie about a voluntary indication of origin. I recommend you to read this.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: answer to two "blue card" questions. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I naturally agree with my colleague who asked the first 'blue card' question because, when I spoke about the current situation, I was referring to the need to implement full labelling, similar to the labelling that already exists for fresh meat. With regard to the second 'blue card' question, I am aware of what you are saying and I agree. On the contrary, our position is to remedy in any way any kind of fraud that may exist in this area. However, of course, voluntary labelling, especially when it comes to those who do not want to label, can be a way of defending against this type of position.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: The indication of the origin of meat used as an ingredient in foodstuffs also has a 90% need among the general public, according to the data communicated by the Commission. We are so proud that we directly represent the European population, so why are the objections here absurdly that this labelling would increase the price of meat by 50%? yes, in case someone's used the sexiest ingredient ever. And now, with the location of origin and the full follow-up, you should look away from that. As one, the Commission has raised the idea that labelling should be that it is outside the EU or outside the EU. Obviously, that's not enough. Although I would add that it is very sad that if the US-EU free trade agreement is reached, even this will be very important. And that is why legislation is urgently needed so that we can prevent cloned, hormone-treated meat products from entering the European market.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to point out that we will vote on Wednesday on a request to the Commission to adopt a legislative proposal on the country of origin indication for meats used in processed foods, not on legislation. Then comes the time of "how" and "when." To say no today is to put an end to any debate on the issue. Some argue, in order to justify their rejection of this resolution, of the increase in costs and administrative burdens. But farmers, like processors, already have an obligation to trace. They must, in fact, keep track of all the products they use. So I find it very difficult to believe that asking for more transparency in this area would lead to such a great complication. Nevertheless, this is an essential point for future negotiations on a legislative proposal. We will have to strike the right balance between the interests of consumers and the competitiveness of our businesses. It should also be remembered that it is a demand from consumers to have more information and more transparency. We must, of course, take into account the possible increase in costs and administrative burdens, but also reconcile consumers with their food, after the various crises we have experienced.  It therefore seems to me to be normal to continue to reflect on this matter, since the analyses contradict each other and our request is indeed, in this context of the resolution, to continue to reflect. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – I wanted to ask a colleague if you are actually satisfied with the information provided by the Commission that this can cost up to 25%, some say that up to 50% is actually satisfied. That's one thing. The second thing, if it's really so expensive, is what do we eat then? What meat?

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I am not convinced by the figures announced by the Commission. The French delegation has some information on production and I would like the Commission to continue its investigations because I do not believe in this 50% increase at all. I think the numbers are much lower and instead of talking about percentages, we should be talking about absolute amounts.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, transparency and the indication of origin of products are two essential elements of European policies. Ensuring the best conditions of transparency promotes the consumption of safe and quality products, linked to the territory and to the typical excellences that the different European regions express and meets the needs of consumers who, we have seen, want to know what they eat and want to know what they are buying. Therefore, the request for a compulsory indication of origin of the meat used as ingredients in processed products goes in exactly this direction. Therefore, while it is right to promote the basic principle of compulsory indication of origin, I believe that at the same time we cannot overlook the fact that the mechanisms for ensuring this greater transparency could also result, as someone else has already said, in a cost to businesses and therefore to consumers.  I listened very carefully to Commissioner Katainen's speech precisely on the cost-benefit ratio that labelling measures may entail. It is precisely in the documentation that the Commission should have already presented that we expect a serious and detailed assessment of these aspects, that is to say, of any additional costs and related operational problems. However, I also think that, should excessive administrative burdens be identified for food business operators and law enforcement authorities, it would be appropriate not to say that nothing is being done, but on the contrary to provide for a whole series of solutions and simplifications on a case-by-case basis in order to better combine transparency and prices that have undoubtedly increased during this period. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Giulia MOI
text: "blue card" question. You have mentioned the burden on businesses so many times. Does this mean that it gives priority and priority to the expenditure of industries that have already made scandals, for example on horsemeat where so many people have been contaminated and intoxicated and so many products have been falsely sold, in order to protect companies? Do you want to give priority to businesses and the small costs that could be there against security for all citizens?

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: answer to a "blue card" question. No, look, I didn't say that, absolutely. I said, however, that in assessing the need – because I consider it a necessity – for compulsory labelling on meat, we cannot overlook the fact that it can – it is not said that it should – lead to an increase in costs not only for the large companies to which you referred, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are often important precisely in the processing action. I therefore believe that, where there are these problems and these excesses of costs, it is one way of saying that we are leaving labelling to one side, but it is another to say that we envisage simplification solutions that precisely meet the sustainability of the system.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, colleagues, the region I represent, Flanders, is known for its good food, its breugelian way of life. "Small Country, Great Food" says it all the way. And that quality is certainly partly due to a strict European policy on food safety, from farm to fork. Quality is also achieved through the use of countless SMEs, every day, small businesses, medium-sized enterprises that work in craft, who are proud of the quality they deliver every day. I am absolutely opposed to the resolution before us for the following four reasons: – origin labelling has nothing to do with security. It does not increase the quality nor the traceability and it does not prevent fraud; – it is operational and practically unfeasible. The sector is rightly soundly sounding the alarm; – it increases administrative burdens and costs and ultimately leads to a higher price for the consumer, who seems to find origin labelling to be relatively important, but does not want to pay extra for it; – finally, this is a taste of protectionism, which is contrary to the principles of the European single market and is particularly to the detriment of smaller, export-oriented regions such as Flanders. We do not need additional rules to restore consumer confidence, but more controls, stricter enforcement of existing agreements and tougher penalties. Voluntary origin labelling for meat as an ingredient already exists and is applied cost-effectively when a clear market demand goes hand in hand with operational feasibility. This can be further worked on. Europe needs more realism and not a flashpoint policy that does not achieve any purpose, but merely creates an unnecessary additional obstacle for the many SMEs in the already precarious economic fabric.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years the EU has been hit by several meat scandals. Consumers were shocked, and rightly so. Food safety must be guaranteed and such fraud must be tackled harshly. However, the European Parliament's call for meat in processed products to be labelled as provenance will not prevent fraud. If someone wants to sell horse meat for beef, a label really doesn't stop him. In Europe, food safety requirements are among the strictest in the world. All products produced or imported in Europe must comply. The meat processing industry uses different meat suppliers from several countries. There is also a lot of change of supplier, so a label would have to be constantly changed. This makes the regulations practically unworkable. The Commission's research shows that this measure increases the cost of production by up to 50%. Such costs are not only borne by the entrepreneur, but also by the consumer. I am therefore not in favour of compulsory labelling of meat in processed products. Producers can voluntarily place this on their label if they wish to distinguish themselves on the market. In conclusion, I would like to say that the call seems sympathetic, but is a wrong instrument. This is unnecessary regulation that does not solve the actual problems. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr President, i would like to thank you for your comments. Would you agree that any labelling costs money? So if costs, is it so understood that we should not label products at all, because every labeling causes costs? And secondly, I would like to ask you whether or not you think there is such a thing as 'consumer patriotism'? Should we ban it in the European Union? It is conceivable that the German consumer wants to buy German meat, the French consumer wants to buy French meat, and the Polish wants to buy It.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, Mr Wojciechowski, thank you for your question. You may be surprised, but no consumer thinks the same. So many people, so many wishes. One would like to know the origin, the other does not want to pay extra for it if the origin is indicated on the label. That is why I am very much in favour of not imposing labelling of origin; producers may voluntarily indicate the origin. And if you are such an advocate of origin labelling on your meat, then you simply buy products that it is listed on.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: Mr President, here is a really radical thought for the Commission: the whole concept that the customer might be right. That seems to stick in the Commission’s throat. It seems to be a problem for it.  At the moment we are being asked to make a decision on very shaky information. The information that we have from the Commission has come from enterprise and business self-reporting. How on earth can we trust that? I trust the consumers, and the consumers say that they want this. One thing, though, that we have to be wary about, and I do agree with the Liberal Member who spoke earlier, is that this cannot be too onerous and too burdensome for the producers, because it will not be the big producers that will be hurt, because they will have the money to do this; it will be the small producers. But it is quite clear that the public wants this and surely the public should get what it wants. I know the Commission very rarely does it, but how about making it a first here?

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Transparency must in fact become the essential principle of food production, and labelling is an opportunity for the consumer to understand this. If we say here on the one hand: 'Fresh meat yes, no in the case of processed meat', that is simply inconsistent. That is why we must consequently take the next step. Now is the time to close this gap. I wonder, of course, why not do this? Two trends in the food industry are clear: "organic" and "regional with a good origin" not only bring higher prices, but also bring more to producers. These trends must also be followed in other areas. On the other hand, there is a food industry that wants to shop cheaply, wants to shop as anonymously as possible, throughout Europe, and as far as possible without control. I am a little surprised that the Commission accepts the arguments of the food industry so unchecked and spreads horror figures, from the fact that the price has been increased by 50%. That has not been proven; there are other studies. However, dear Commission, but also the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, let us work together on workable solutions on how we can implement labelling, but not to block it here and to offer the consumer no solutions at all. We must further increase confidence in European food. That is a task for us. And the fact that this will ultimately lead to consumers appreciating European food on the basis of the safety tested has become clear in recent years and has been evident in many places. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Häusling, you have just said that we do not have any controls. Is that really the case? You really need to know better. After all, we have an improbable number of regulations for food production, for the right quality – which I think is a good thing. We therefore already have the origin labelling requirement for fresh meat. We have many other high-quality standards, which we want to defend, especially in the case of TTIP. Do you really believe what you are saying, namely that there are no controls? That is not the case. On the contrary, are there perhaps not too few controls? Is it not the case that fraudsters in particular have the opportunity to slip through the hole because there is too little control under the existing laws? Isn't that enough?

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Ladies and gentlemen, I did not say that we do not have any controls. I have said that industry would prefer fewer controls. We could have implemented few legal requirements if we had always listened to the complaints of the industry. They were also opposed to the labelling of fresh meat. So, as politicians, we are not making ourselves the chief lobbyist of an industry, but we are consistently implementing consumer wishes! It may also be necessary to act in the end against those who think that they represent an entire industry and its well-being. There are many who have gained advantages in the market with clear labelling and good rules, and we should listen to them.

name: Julia REID
text: Mr President, the powers that be must not muddle three separate issues as, although they appear identical, they are in reality distinct. The first is bad food, food which makes people ill. This is the most serious of the three and the solutions are good practice, hygiene, and, for when things go wrong, traceability. You must know the entire route from farm to table and be able to identify where and how the problem happened.  The second is fake food. Food which does not make people ill but is not what it says. This is basically a matter of due diligence and contract law. In fact, commercial interests police this pretty well most of the time.  The third is the consumer’s right to know what they are buying. Linked to this is nutritional science, which has to be based on science that does not date: for example, fat and sugar in the diet, which may be about to undergo a revolution as a result of our better understanding of the role of insulin in the body.  We must not saddle industry and consumers with requirements which are just about to be proved wrong. Any regime must properly and sensibly meet the needs of all three without confusing them either in law or in the public mind. Unfortunately, as a result of the EU’s usual lack of clear thinking, they are at the moment horribly muddled.

name: Iveta GRIGULE-PĒTERSE
text: We consumers have the right to know what we eat, what our children eat, what our parents eat. Meat producers, farmers, are also interested in such labelling, because they want to develop their own brands, their own quality marks. Yes, processors and intermediaries are against and not so much because it will make the product a little more expensive, but because it is easier to hide the country of origin and the place of origin. Let us not forget that we will soon be flooded with cheap meat from America, whose cultivation and production uses genetically modified feed. We've heard stories of chicken from America treated with chlorine.  Do we want to know? Yes, we want to know what we eat, we have the right to know. And I am really surprised whether there is any objection to openness in this high house, does the Commission have anything to hide?

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I think this is a very useful discussion, regardless of the fact that we have very different opinions here. We would all like consumers to have confidence in the food supply chain, we would like to see food counterfeiting, and the example of horsemea added to beef, as has happened, is proof that counterfeiting is ing. We would also like animals to be fed good feed. After all, we remember the affair – also european – with dioxins or remember the issue of BSE. But at the same time, the introduction of meat labelling in products is often regarded as a certain panacea for improving supply chain control and preventing irregularities. The question therefore arises: if we want to prevent these irregularities or counterfeiting, should we not better enforce a law that already exists?  Many consumers, but also many manufacturers, are talking about over-regulation in the European Union, not about its absence. And now the question is: will increasing the information on the labels radically improve this situation? Secondly, there is also the question of the country of origin, whether it is the origin of the animals or the place where the animal was slaughtered or the place where the carcase was cutting. Should this whole chain be on the label? Although I think it is important, mr Wojciechowski's remark, which speaks of consumer patriotism, is valuable. I am a supporter of slow food, so I understand it very well. The labelling of the origin of ingredients should first of all be permitted and this should, in my opinion, be the brand of the manufacturer concerned. I think that if we had achieved this, then we could have achieved certain standards much easier.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Mr. President! This motion for a resolution on the labelling of the origin of processed meat in food calls on the European Commission to take action. We know that 90% of EU consumers want to know where the meat they want to enjoy in pizza, lasagna or meatballs comes from. I would also like to respond a little to some of the arguments that have been put forward here. First of all, there is the argument that it makes food much more expensive. I believe that apples have been compared to pears here and that we need to talk about production costs on the one hand and costs for consumers, that is to say for consumers, on the other. There will be big differences. I think the 50% or up to 50% that were in the report is far too high. I believe that there will be significantly less and that consumers will then be happy to pay one cent more. I would like to make another argument here. This is where producer interests meet with consumer interests. At the same time, we would be using labelling to ensure that the dumping competition of meat traders is restricted and that there is more regionality, in other words, that smaller cycles are preferred. That is why I am strongly promoting this motion for a resolution and I hope that we will respond to the consumer's wishes. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Do you not think that meat producers, i.e. farmers, are under even more price pressure as an ingredient as a means of mandatory labelling of meat as an ingredient? As far as I know, the price pressure on meat is already quite not insignificant.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for that question. I just don't think so. I believe that producers also have an interest in ensuring that we have good products and that the appropriate price is paid for them, and that relations between producers and consumers are also becoming much stronger – as Mr Häusling has already mentioned – so we want to know where the meat comes from and that it is preferred from the region in a small cycle. What you mean is the meat merchants. I am strongly in favour of countering dumping competition at this point.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking If we mark the country of origin of wine and this information is extremely important to consumers, why should we not determine the origin of the meat, both unprocessed and processed?
