This is not just about quality, but it is about a number of other information that matters to consumers. This is because the European market, although single, has different rules on many issues, e.g. on ritual slaughter – most countries allow this slaughter, but there are countries that do not allow it, and this is important information for many consumers that they buy meat from a country where there is no ritual slaughter. Or the use of genetically modified feed – my country Poland is preparing to introduce (there is even a law in this regard) a ban on the use of feed from genetically modified organisms, and this can be important information for the consumer that meat from Polish is meat from animals fed with feed without GMOs. Finally, this 'consumer patriotism' (thank you, Mr Grzyb, appreciated this). Of course, this is also an important issue and we should respect the fact that consumers want to know whether a meat product is from his country or from another country.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr. President! I am absolutely in favour of consumers being transparent about the food they can buy. I also think it is absolutely right that we have very strict food regulations in Europe, which must also be monitored – perhaps not always monitored enough. The horsemeat scandal, there had really been officially cheated. Beef was given, and horsemeat was in it. We cannot prevent this by not labelling the world. We must try to catch up with those who want to cheat. Absolutely right! But what is the point of really having labelling for processed meat in various finished products? Is it really important for us to know whether a particular meat ingredient comes from Denmark or Poland or Germany? As long as we can trust – if the controls are correct – that all this has been done sensibly. Do we know, for example, whether meat that Comes from Denmark is guaranteed to be better in quality than if it came from somewhere else? We have the same quality requirements everywhere. That is why I do not think it is decisive. I think consumers want good quality, and they want transparency about that. There is no point in knowing which of the European countries is coming from.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Mr President, every year millions of animals are dragged all over Europe as if they were irons. These animals are sometimes packed together for days in overcrowded trains, cattle trucks, planes or boats. Their journey usually ends in the slaughterhouse. And why? Because slaughter in Romania is a few pennies cheaper. Or because parma ham has to be made from fresh ham in Parma. A good provenance label with information about place of birth, rearing, growing up and slaughtering the animals, makes these absurd animal transports visible. Such a label gives consumers the opportunity to opt for real local products and makes meat and meat fraud more traceable. We are very much in favour of this proposal. We would also like to see information on animal welfare, because we are still completely missing from this, and we would like to see the meat of more animal species, including horse meat, added. Mr President, I also believe that agricultural subsidies should be abolished! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8).)

name: József NAGY
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask the Member if she has thought about how such a law or such a change would rearrange the entire market, the agricultural meat market. And how, how unjustified resettlement would lead to, as far as meat production is concerned. So you talked about animals in trucks. Let us think back to the european Union's support for diversification, i.e. territorial distribution of livestock production precisely to protect, for example, our groundwater or to protect the quality of our soil. And if we focus on the places where the meat product itself is going to be produced, we're going to backtrack. Think of it as, for example, Denmark, where they support diversifying, i.e. moving livestock farming further away.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: "blue card" answer. – Thank you for this question. It is clear that consumers also want this diversification. They prefer products made in their own region, so they know where they come from. At the moment it is absolutely impossible to see where the salami or pizza was produced and under what conditions. We think it is important that you put this on the label, so that consumers simply have the opportunity to make a really good choice without long animal transports.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a highly globalised food market – and, among other things, on the doorstep of the negotiations on the TTIP Free Trade Treaty which, in our view, could bring dangers and pitfalls for European citizens and consumers – live animals and their meat travel thousands of kilometres and are processed and processed often only with a view to maximising profit. However, the consumer has the right to choose his purchases freely. Therefore, concepts such as transparency, access to information and food safety are crucial, not least in the light of the study which shows that 90% of consumers want to know the origin of the meat of processed products. It is therefore bizarre to note that the Impact Study carried out by the Commission on compulsory labelling provides for an increase in costs, and therefore in prices, for operators in the sector, when these data are the result of consultations with the industry alone without the necessary involvement of other stakeholders and especially consumer associations. It would therefore be important for any increase in costs to be based precisely on official data or objective scientific data. In addition, a final question relates to the possible implementation of what is the short supply chain even in Europe in a more convincing way.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Mr President, I believe it is essential today that consumers can eat safely. The traceability of meat should be supplemented by other indications such as where it is farmed, for example, how to feed it, and how it is slaughtered.  Your economic system is based on three groups: first, producers, who want to make a decent living from their work by making quality, then, consumers, who want to eat healthily and, in between, the large middle groups, which aim only at profitability.  Alas, the European Union has been relying on these for thirty years, imposing on us the principle of polluters ruining. They pollute by making food travel thousands of kilometres between their production and consumption, ruin French producers by unfair competition and, moreover, deceive consumers on products.  It is time for the European Commission to put an end to this system, in the interests of all. I also believe that labelling will strengthen the position of national and local sectors. Moreover, our compatriots want to relocate the processing industries as close as possible to the production, which will reduce costs, a guarantee of support to national sectors, thus food security and sovereignty.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we are talking here about something that is obvious to everyone. We are talking about something that the citizens of Europe want, that 90% of them want. We need to regain credibility and confidence on the part of our fellow citizens. It seems to me to be very simple: we must continue to work on the label that tells the origin of the meat. A very serious mistake was made in the last parliamentary term with the regulation which removed the obligation to indicate the production plant in the products of the major brands. We have had a rebellion from our consumers and now, in my country, for example, it is happening that not only is the government thinking of running for cover but, indeed, the big supermarket chains are buying the pages of the newspapers to advertise and say that they will continue to put that indication of the establishment. It seems to me today that we are in a Parliament which, by a large majority, wants to continue working along these lines. As far as costs are concerned, we already have Regulation (EC) No 178/2002 which asks companies to have and maintain this information to be given to the competent authorities when they request it. Let us not be overwhelmed by those who, already in the last parliamentary term, led us to slam and make us take the wrong decision.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: All the polls show that Europeans want to know where the food they eat comes from. One of the reasons is the desire to buy domestic products to support local producers. Another may be trying to avoid food brought in from thousands of miles away because of the huge environmental impact. There are people who want to know details about the origin of food for religious reasons. However, clearly, the main factor influencing this decision is the cost, and on the labelling requirements and, in particular, the requirement to specify the country of origin of the food, it was said that it would lead to an increase in prices. The Commission must certainly consider this impact of labelling regulations very carefully. So far, the Commission's studies are based on reports from the food industry. There are, however, also external studies that indicate different results. We need a much more serious analysis of the potential costs before denying consumers the right to be informed. We already have rules that require country of origin labelling in the case of fresh meat and we have food safety traceability systems. So the systems already exist and are functional. I therefore do not believe that an increase in food prices would be justified if this information were also communicated to consumers through labels.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The citizens of the European Union want and have the right to know where the meat products they eat come from. They call for the possibility of making choices based on the knowledge of where the meat comes from, whether the product is genetically modified or whether it comes from cloned animals. Mandatory inclusion of information on the origin of processed meat and, above all, systematic control of food quality is a necessary step in order to regain consumer confidence. The Commission's report indicates a significant increase in production costs as a result of the change in labels, while studies by consumer organisations show that these costs will not increase significantly. In the interests of citizens' rights and health, the European Commission should propose specific regulations to this end, including minimising the additional financial burden.

name: Marit PAULSEN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul After all, we humans have a genetic and cultural heritage that requires us to know what we eat. Most people get worried if you're not exactly sure what's in the package. This makes an old-fashioned life extremely difficult in a time and a society when all food is well packed in plastic bags. We can't see it, we can't smell it, we can't taste it, we can't do anything.  So it is our obvious duty to ensure that the information is accessible to our citizens. But it is also our absolute duty as legislators and elected representatives to simultaneously create control systems, so that we do not make lies and fraud more accessible than it is today.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, shopping is a political act which is becoming more important every day in this globalised world. When we buy, we can decide to support local agriculture, production in the hands of the peasant, small and medium-sized local industries, and also local trade. Or, on the contrary, we can support the large industry, the large distribution and those industries that care very little about everything other than their benefits. On the other hand, if we can choose to buy on short circuits, we are contributing in an important way to the fight against climate change, which apparently worries us so much. But we are also acting against energy waste, which is no small thing considering that we have reached the peak of oil. But for all this, so that we can decide freely, we need labeling. We need to know the country of origin of our food, also of meat in processed products and also of seafood, which in my country, in Galicia, we are also very deeply concerned about.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! There is an urgent need to designate the country of origin of meat, including on foods that are processed, because there are major differences in quality within the Union, both in livestock farming and in meat processing. Moreover, the plans for trade agreements such as TTIP suggest that more processed food from third countries should also enter the European market. In the absence of a labelling requirement, quality standards are undermined and the cheapest and not the best products prevail on the market. I am still thinking with horror of the meat scandal in 2013. Strict rules are needed in the interests of consumers. This is the only way to restore consumer confidence in products. Food producers should be forced to take greater care and greater responsibility in the selection of their suppliers, because it must be clear that good food must also come at a price!

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I, too, am clearly in favour of maximum transparency as regards the origin of our food. In particular, I believe that meat labelling would be a very great benefit, on the one hand for consumers and, on the other hand, for agriculture. I also believe that this horsemeat scandal in particular – not the horse of the scandal, but the wrong labelling – could not be prevented by a law and a new directive. If someone wants to cheat, they will probably continue to do so in the future. Nevertheless, I believe that we are creating more transparency for consumers by means of mandatory origin labelling for processed products. It doesn't really have to be labeled every slice of salami on a pizza. I think it is also clear that this goes absolutely too far. But a minimum of origin marking is absolutely necessary. Here I am in favour of a combined approach of compulsory and voluntary labelling. The introduction of a mandatory minimum labelling of origin "from the EU" or "not from the EU" for sausage and meat products probably costs the industry virtually nothing, but nevertheless creates clear conditions, especially as regards the purchase of raw materials. There have also been scandals in my region on a number of occasions. I believe that the possibility of voluntary labelling is particularly important. A country like Austria has a very high level of awareness here. I am also convinced that this would primarily support small and medium-sized enterprises and would also help them. Because if we look at the manufacturing industry today, it gets the cheapest raw material products everywhere. We could put a stop to this here.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his I agree with all the previous speakers who have today called on the Commission to present a draft law on mandatory origin labelling of meat in processed foods, because I feel here as a consumer representative and do not see myself as a lobbyist for food companies, as some other speakers have suggested. Consumers have a right to transparency and traceability, whether the meat is freshly processed or unprocessed. 90% of Europeans also demand this information. To portray such a request as stupid or nonsensical is, in my view, stupid and nonsensical. What I am also opposed to, however, is to be put in the right corner for my position, to be placed as a protectionist, because I believe that consumers want to make informed, informed decisions. In order to make these decisions, they need the information. What they then begin with the information is their decision – whether they put together their personal diet or whether they simply make the decision to favour meat from certain regions, from certain Member States, simply out of environmental considerations, from animal welfare considerations. This must be the right of every single European, of consumers. This has nothing to do with protectionism. I think it is really stupid to want to tell consumers that they should not know anything. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: József NAGY
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask my colleague whether he does not feel that these steps represent the deliberalisation of the European internal market. Would it be acceptable for you, for example, to include the origin of eggs, milk and then flour on each product after, say, an egg scandal? This would completely paralyze the efficient procurement of raw materials in the food industry in Europe.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. We must not always wait for scandals before anything happens. An Austrian proverb says that something must not always happen for something to happen. We have this labelling in the beef sector as a result of the BSE scandal. It worked there. In other words, I do not want to wait until these scandals exist in the case of pigmeat, poultry or other things, but I believe that this right to inform the consumer of meat, but also in future with eggs or milk, is a good right. When it comes to meat, we have enough occasions.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: Mr President, I have enjoyed this debate here this evening. I think it is a very good debate because there is little doubt that the horsemeat events and the scandal of 2013 did rock consumer confidence and confidence in the processing industry. Consumers felt rightly cheated, and the honest meat producers were totally undermined. I remember at that time going to visit the local butcher’s shop and what they were experiencing at that time was an increase of over 20% in people going from supermarkets to the local butcher’s shop where they actually felt they were getting what they were promised.  Now I have to say to people: if you believe the advertisements of the supermarkets, that you can get four hamburgers for a pound, do not be surprised if what you were promised is not actually there. So, you know, there is also another aspect to this. We should not allow the large supermarkets to tell us these things or to browbeat those in the processing industry to provide them with the loss leaders that force people to do these sorts of things.  Now the horsemeat scandal had nothing to do with that. That was pure corruption. People out to destroy the industry. People changing meat on computers. The meat never moved! It was done on computers. It was a ridiculous situation that never, ever should be allowed to occur again. But let us have common sense and let us try and get a system that is not overly costly but will work.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, it's only a matter of time before all labels clearly state whether the meat is from cloned animals, whether the meat fed on GMO and, of course, what country of origin it is. If today we know on the label how much sodium there is in meat or how many calories, as I as you can see, I don't read too much of those details, but how many calories there is a single piece of salami or something else, then I guess it's clear that these labels should clearly indicate whether the meat is from cloned animals, whether it's from GMO, what country of origin it is. Etc.  I come from Croatia and I know that we import meat from Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia and other countries that are not members of the European Union and of course this is something that our consumers want to know. That's why I tend to be inclined to those who advocate the need to make everything clear on labels, because that's what consumers expect of us.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Mr President, in theory it seems positive to us that information on the origin of meat used in processed foods may be visible on the label. We could even extend this standard to all the ingredients of these products. We have, however, doubts about the operationality of this standard.  This issue, as is invariate in this European Union, is the result of a scandal with an impact on the media and which has pushed the institutions into law without a mature reflection on the problems. It is one thing to tamper with a product with the incorporation of horsemeat, illegally; it is another thing to impose labelling with the mention of geographical origin in the meat shares in the processed food without looking at the costs that this entails for the row and without taking care whether there are control mechanisms to enable the authorities to ensure that these standards are actually met.  Not having a closed position on this, these are doubts that would be important to discuss, without rushing into a standard that will always have a strong impact, especially in the level of small and medium-sized enterprises in the sector.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, mandatory labelling of origin is a matter for certain regions and Member States in their product marketing, at the expense of the European food sector and internal market, not of combating food fraud. Food fraud is combated with equal enforcement in the EU, effective inspection, not with unnecessary, useless extra bureaucracy. The processed fresh meat must already be traceable and mandatory labelled by origin. No double bureaucracy. Mandatory labelling of provenance leads to excessive additional production costs for our Dutch and European SMEs and food producers and is a huge bureuacratic burden for artisanal middle classes and entrepreneurs. Bureaucracy that we, as the EPP, want to reduce in the Juncker Commission. This leads to expensive food products at a time of increasing shortage and economic recession in parts of the EU. Our Dutch pea soup and your pizza will be up to 10 percent more expensive. I'm not talking about 50 percent. Don't do this to the consumer. It does not want any obligation with this large price increase as a result. Don't do this to our caterer, our caterer and artisan butcher, and neither does the farmer!

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, during the last parliamentary term we defined the regulation on food labelling and managed as a Parliament to make the origin of all meat compulsory on the label, just as was previously the case only for beef. This was a great result of transparency, so we fought for a long time as a Parliament and it was welcomed by consumers. We now welcome the fact that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy has moved towards more transparent labelling systems. During the last parliamentary term, the Committee on Agriculture approved the opinion on the regulation on consumer information, including the obligation of origin for processed products, single ingredients. Consumers need to know the origin of food in order to make informed choices and not to be conditioned in the choices by labelling systems such as that of traffic lights, which even goes so far as to brand extra virgin olive oil as a food dangerous to health. However, it must be made clear that the indication of origin on the label is not a system for combating food fraud, which requires a strengthening of controls and sanctions. The sadly well-known case of horsemeat in lasagna was a case of food fraud that would not have been avoided even with compulsory origin labelling.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Consumers in European Union countries are fed up with food scandals with meat of unknown origin. The bitterness was overwhelmed by the 2013 horsemeon affair, which found itself instead of beef in processed products such as burgers and lasagna. It is therefore necessary to indicate the country of origin of the meat, not only of unprocessed pig and poultry meat – to be done from April this year – but also of processed meat used as an ingredient in other products. Recognising that the need to mark the country of origin of meat in processed food products may lead to an increase in their prices due to additional administrative measures, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, I believe, however, that consumer safety should come first. It is also necessary to effectively control the provisions introduced so that companies using meat in their products are aware that any breach of those rules will be met with an immediate appropriate response from the inspection bodies.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks for this debate, which we are having this evening on this very emotional issue. It is very important to me that European consumers are able to find out about their food in a transparent and reliable manner. Confidence in our agricultural products must come first. However, we must not patronise our citizens. The consumer should weigh up quality and price himself. I therefore am absolutely convinced that we should take into account the increased desire for regionality in the origin of our food. Protected designations of origin and indications are important and enriching to serve certain markets. Of course, the idea of a single European internal market must not be harmed here. I believe that a debate on the further development of voluntary labelling in processed meat would be necessary and also more effective than relying on commitments. In this way, I believe that the central aspect would be taken into account, that is to say, that the added value for the consumer would be given and that the additional bureaucratic burden on businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, would be proportionate, desirable and, in the end, also worthwhile.

name: Pavel POC
text: Mr President, this debate today is such a déjà vu, it is not new, we have already experienced it here, we experienced it here a few years ago, and even then there were the same objections that were based on the lobbyist materials of the processors. Even then, there was a risk of price increases. We have only partially succeeded, and so in the meantime there have been a number of food fraud scandals and there has been a significant reduction in consumer confidence. That's the result.  Now the results of the European Consumer Association survey show that more than 90% of respondents want the origin of the meat to be clearly identified. Consumers would not only welcome such information on packaging, but rather wonder that the information is no longer there, because they do not understand why processed meat should not be subject to the same strict and high-quality regulations as unprocessed meat. Regardless of which State of the Union the rules are enforced. We are not talking about any small amount of meat, in some EU countries up to half of all meat products are due to this condition without any indication of place of origin, and this is, in my opinion, alarming. There is so much lobbying around it now, so much scaremongering by price increases and bureaucracy, that I feel that this debate is really in the right place, and it needs to show, among other things, who is listening, whether it is consumers or industry. After all, we will vote on whether the Commission should work on the proposal at all, not on the legislation itself. So why does anyone want to kill the debate in the very germ?  And if we are to ask the Commission a question today, I would ask the question of price in particular. We really agree that the price is key, we agree that customers don't want to pay. But some producers have already taken such a softening in some form, and they are clearly competitive, and this raises the fundamental question of whether the Commission drew on the fear of the right sources or whether it assessed, for example, the results of investigations by consumer organisations.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: Food safety and traceability of food products and by-products must be absolute priorities of the authorities at European and national level. Practice has shown us, however, that simply labelling the country of origin or place of origin of meat does not prevent fraud in the food sector or improve food safety. Such regulation would only increase the level of information of citizens. I support a voluntary labelling system of the origin of meat products that allows Member States to opt for the introduction of such regulation. At both national and European level, there are authorities responsible for ensuring traceability of products to ensure consumer safety, and we need to ensure that these institutions work effectively. In some countries, such as my country, where purchasing power is low because of low incomes, where small and medium-sized enterprises producing consumer products are an important part of the food sector, it is difficult to talk about such a regulation that can bring an additional administrative burden, as well as increases in manufacturing costs, thus, by implication, higher costs of food consumed by citizens. My personal position, which is the same as that of Romania and most of my group, is to keep the voluntary labelling system today.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Mr. Chairman, esteemed colleagues, the question of marking the origin of meat concerns each of us. After major scandals and scams with the mesa, there was a need for a legal solution that would make such cases impossible or at least more difficult. That is why we need to send a clear signal to the European Commission to propose new rules. A declaration that does not provide details on the origin of meat is simply not fair to consumers and paves the way for various scams.  Such a situation can be solved relatively easily and at no great cost to manufacturers. After all, if we talk about costs, I find consumer trust to be simply invaluable. Furthermore, labelling the country of origin of meat will make it easier for national authorities to combat food fraud and punish perpetrators.  I believe that this is in the interest of European consumers, because as already mentioned, 90% want to know where the meat they eat is from. The Common Market of the European Union opens up a number of choice options for consumers and producers, but sometimes it also opens loopholes exploited by reckless speculators. Such loopholes should be closed and health and consumer rights further protected.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr President, can I just say that I do not quite see this debate as it has been framed by many here this evening, that is about it being industry versus consumers. I do not think it is as black and white as that. I also do not think it is any surprise that when we ask consumers if they want the country of origin labelling they will say yes, and I do not think it is any surprise that they are not prepared to pay more for it, but in my view this debate should be much more about the sustainability of the food supply chain.  In my view, reputable food producers, whether of products with processed meats or otherwise, have sustainable long-term relationships with their suppliers and therefore should not have the need to switch and swap between those suppliers. That is how I come to this debate. I am torn between the debate about what consumers want and what they are prepared to pay for. I do not see this on the Commission’s work programme for this year. I think it requires more debate but I would ask us to do it in the context of the sustainability of the food supply chain, above all else, and having these long-term supplier relationships. Lastly, can I say that on the issue of fraud you can stick on a fraudulent label. The issue of food fraud will only be tackled when we monitor and control the food supply chain adequately.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Much has been said, but for me the issue of origin marking of processed meat is important. When I meet parents in my country, Sweden, there are very many people who are concerned about the quality of the food. They are concerned about animal husbandry, they are concerned about the risks of additives and chemicals, in short, they are concerned about the health of their children. Many have said so, but 90% of consumers want origin marking of processed food.  We are currently living in a time where food can be transported easily and cheaply over very long distances. It is a very long time since we knew where the food came from and where it was usually nearby, in our own region or country. Nowadays it is increasingly further away from people's everyday lives. How can you as a consumer easily know that people, animals and nature are taken into account in the world we live in now? I am convinced that the origin marking of meat is a necessary reform. It is a necessary reform in the time we live. Consumers want this power to choose. It's time we give it to them.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, in the aftermath of the horsemeat scandal, attention has been stepped up to food labelling, and that is a good thing. As a young European consumer, I am, of course, also opposed to fraud and for greater food safety and transparency. To my surprise, however, I find that in this House people think that a compulsory nationality listing is by definition a guarantee of safe food. But let's be honest with each other. It is not the country of origin of meat that determines its safety, but the way the producer works. I have ears to the concerns of consumers who want more clarity about their food, but on the basis of scientific facts. We know that 75% of consumers do not want or in some cases cannot afford the additional costs of compulsory origin labelling. If we really want to build a more social Europe, we cannot have the intention of adopting a measure that makes the lives of the weakest even more expensive. And how sincere do we sound about strengthening measures for SMEs when we are chasing those same entrepreneurs through the back door for costs? How consistent is our agricultural policy if, through cost increases for meat processing companies, we are jeopardising farmers' already small profit margins? Finally, Mr President, I hear every day among young people the call for a europe to recruit, a less meddling Europe. Well, it is very questionable whether this measure meets this call. I think we all know the answer to that.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! At this late stage, of course, it is difficult to add a great deal of new to the debate, but I would like to join the vast majority here this evening in favour of, of course, labelling where our processed meat comes from. Yes, in fact, I cannot understand why it should be a problem at all. Of course, we have a right to know where our processed meat comes from. Not least in a globalised world where food passes through the supply chain across many countries and across many continents, it can be really difficult for consumers to get an idea of what kind of food is a food that is being provided with. So it is perfectly reasonable to demand to know which country a food comes from.  We also talked about the horsemeat scandal tonight. It was a fraud, but it taught us one thing. It is that a great many companies do not have control over their supply chains. Therefore, a legal requirement for the labelling of processed meat, where it comes from, can help them to get a handle on these supply chains. Yes, it will probably cost a little more, but i wonder if the prices presented by the industry are exaggerated slightly.  Commissioner, try to listen to consumers for once. Confidence in food in the EU single market is not as high as it could be. Country of origin labelling can help to increase this confidence!

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a resolution on the labelling of origin for processed products submitted to us is welcome, and I support it. While labelling the origin of all meats will soon become a reality in Europe, the European Parliament has continued its claim for the introduction of country-of-origin labelling for processed meat products. As you know, this requirement corresponds to a very high consumer expectation, as 90% of them demand it. Our assembly recalled the need in the wake of the horsemeat scandal in my region in France. It is certain that labelling the origin of processed food products, by improving traceability, will increase transparency and thus consumer confidence, and thus improve economic recovery and employment in many territories.  We are therefore now looking forward to the commission's legislative proposals, which will have to take into account the consequences on business costs and on administrative constraints.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, this debate is about a better balance between greater consumer information and the cost burden of any measures that would be proposed. I have heard many comments tonight about big industry versus the consumer. I do not think it is about big industry really, when you see the costs that the Commission has put forward in terms of the cost of providing the labelling of food origin. I think we need to look at and focus on the small and medium enterprises, who I speak to regularly, who are involved in processing of food. They say that this will result in increased cost to them in producing the products they produce and then ultimately to the consumer, because the consumer is always the bottom of the chain and will certainly absorb these costs. I think really it is the small and medium businesses along this route, the businesses to whom we promised that this Commission would not introduce more red tape – would use better regulation and not more regulation – who need to be the centre of this debate. I am not convinced that mandatory labelling will protect the consumer. As I said, this is not a food safety issue, it is a consumer information issue, but also it is about the price to the consumer. That needs to be the centre of our deliberations tonight.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 90% of citizens think it is important that the origin of meats used as an ingredient be mentioned, and this has been said many times. Consumers need to be informed. The Commission uses the argument of a significant increase in prices in the event of an obligation to mention the origin of meat. This is obviously not the truth, it is the argument of the agri-food industry, which does not want to change anything. In truth, for companies that voluntarily mentioned the origin indication, the extra cost was estimated at 0.67 per cent, or a few cents. What costs is the number of intermediaries, many of whom are useless. This would cost consumers much less if there were fewer intermediaries in the sector and if a more decent price could be paid to producers. The Commission must listen to consumer organisations and the European Parliament must listen to both sides of the chain: producers, who are suffering, and consumers, who are in demand. Commissioner, you are on the grill; we expect legislation from you. A little courage, please.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the issue of food safety is crucial for the health of consumers. That is why labelling is necessary. Several food scandals are already known in the European Union, which have created a lack of confidence in the functioning of the single internal market. It is now clear that consumers, in particular the country of origin, must be fully informed of meat in processed foods. Of course, the increase in quality leads to an increase in food prices, but not to the level arbitrarily identified by industries. But we need to really know what we're eating. Because we don't want to eat mutant foods. We do not want to consume meat of cloned animals. We don't want beef mixed with horse meat. That is why it is important to inform the consumer; because we want safe and quality food. Traceability is therefore crucial for the proper functioning of the economy itself. That's why consumers prefer local products.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, depending on the Member State and how the internal market in food products is regulated, as well as customer confidence in what they find on the shelves of their stores on a daily basis, consumer opinions differ when it comes to labelling the origin of meat used as an ingredient in food.  Unlike some Member States, in Croatia we have had very negative experiences with frozen meat coming from imports to our market several years old and several years old, so on this occasion I welcome the recent entry into force of the new regulation on informing consumers about food.  When it comes to processed products containing meat, sometimes I dread to think about what comes on our plates, even from some members of the European Union. I support the labelling of the country of origin of meat used as an ingredient in food.  I personally believe that consumers need to be provided with complete information about the food they are buying. My view is that meat labelling should also contain information on the place and date of slaughter of the animal, so that consumers have full information about each of the key events in the animal's cycle, such as the place and time of birth, breeding and slaughter of the animal. So, I am advocating the traceability of ingredients in the food chain, which would reduce the scope for unfair trading practices, but also evident play-offs of the law.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: In practice, today's summary of this debate is probably that consumers do want to be clear about where the different meat products come from. And those who have tried to counter this, I say to them, every meat processor, if it is necessary to indicate the origin of the raw material, will think a hundred times what they will put in their product. And that is what helps european citizens' food security. And it's not that they still have to eat different products with their eyes closed. I think it's a benign initiative, we're going to find a normal solution so that the food industry doesn't get involved, but we should all be happy about it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, regulating any industry is very delicate and requires special caution. Unfortunately, the legislature too often introduces new rules under pressure from interest groups, while I believe that our task is to find a balance between industry and consumers so that the end customer is fully informed and protected and that industrial production remains sustainable and profitable.  The latest horsemeed scandal has laid off the shortfall in regulations so far and focused public attention on the meat industry. While I believe that we should not overdo regulation and thus increase production and harm the industry, I think restoring consumer confidence in the meat industry would also benefit meat producers. That is why I hope that any future proposals will maximise the protection of the European consumer, but also keep the industry from excessive additional costs.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, deciding to make the labelling of processed meat compulsory in the various foods we consume on a daily basis is an important goal in order to ensure better traceability, avoid food fraud with serious consequences for citizens and help food companies to choose better suppliers and products. The only regret is that we have not included a reference to traceability of meat from cloned animals and entering our territories from third countries. We have no certainty as to the effects produced, let alone where they come from. We hope that the Commission will take this into account and clarify the whole food chain. European citizens must have the right to know and the freedom to choose. Europe has not only the responsibility but above all the duty to inform its citizens of where they come from.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, thank you for a very deep, fine and fruitful debate. We have taken note of your views and I will pass these on to my colleague Vytenis Andriukaitis, who will be in charge of this particular issue. I would also like to underline that the estimated increase of 15% - 20% and up to 50% referred to the additional operating costs for the industry and not to the final product price. It is very difficult to estimate what kind of impact this would have on the final product cost. This depends firstly on the animal species concerned, secondly on the specific product concerns, on the applicable modalities, and fourthly on the specific operational situation of the operation concerned. The French study cannot be compared to the Commission report because it only concerns beef, and second only in France, and third only voluntary schemes. It focuses on price increases whereas the Commission report focused on increases in operating costs. The Commission report also examined the willingness of the consumer to pay for information on origin, and this was found to be very weak. This aspect has not been assessed in other consumer surveys. As I said, I will take all the speeches here today to my colleague Vytenis Andriukaitis.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(1) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 11 February 2015.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – Mandatory origin labelling on products containing meat is really not a good measure. It doesn't help to fight fraud. The recent horsemeat scandal used horsemeat instead of beef, which is outright fraud and origin labelling would have changed nothing. Moreover, food control is already very well regulated in Europe. All meat can be traced from the feed supplier to the store. We need to focus even more on the fight against fraud, not on additional legislation. Producers who voluntarily want to indicate the origin of the meat on their products are, of course, free to do so, but we are not in favour of an obligation. For meat processors, this measure would be an additional administrative burden and would entail additional costs, which will inevitably be passed on to the consumer.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Mandatory country-of-origin indication of meat used in processed foods is essential for consumer protection and the fight against food fraud. We must learn from the horsemeat scandal. The European Union must impose strict meat labelling to improve the traceability of processed foods. We find that consumers are increasingly concerned with knowing exactly what they are eating and where they are eating. It is our duty as a legislator to respond to this perfectly legitimate request.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The motion for a resolution we are debating, by strengthening the principle of compulsory indication of origin of meat, could help to restore the confidence of European consumers and at the same time reaffirm this Parliament's strong sensitivity to consumer health and the proper functioning of the food chain. I believe that this resolution has the great merit of giving a concrete response to the 90% of European citizens who, according to a recent report by the European Commission, consider it important to indicate the origin of meat on the label of processed products and who are calling for greater transparency throughout the food chain in order to be able to make more informed choices. With this resolution, Parliament has the opportunity to give a strong signal to the European Commission, prompting it to put in place a legislative initiative on the labelling of processed meat, which should aim to strike a balance between transparency and competitiveness, ensuring a conscious choice for consumers.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – The first objective of food labelling is to provide coherent and transparent information so that the consumer makes an informed choice. Many European companies meet this expectation by providing information on the origin of the product as a voluntary practice. Addressing a 'measure that fits all', requiring mandatory labelling of the origin of meat used as an ingredient in processed foods would have severe negative consequences for food manufacturers, farmers, retailers and consumers, would create significant problems in the supply chain, leading to possible major disruptions and inefficiencies, with the potential to increase consumer prices and food waste. All this could result in a less competitive European food chain. As far as the consumer is concerned, a balanced measure must be identified to ensure that he is not aware, but without significant increases in the prices of meat products and without increasing the administrative burden for both the authorities and operators of the agro-industrial sector, which are already facing financial difficulties due to the economic crisis.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament's Environment Committee adopted a motion for a resolution on 21 January on the labelling of meat used in processed foods in the country of origin. This week we will be called upon to vote again on this resolution, in which we call on the European Commission to be more vigilant on the labelling of processed dishes. The resolution calls on the European Commission to present a new legislative proposal to the European Parliament to do so. Current regulations provide for mandatory labelling for meat, but the provisions for processed dishes are not being implemented at this time. This situation is not satisfactory, and further momentum is needed. Although I ask the question of the ability of Member States to ensure the effectiveness of controls across the production chain, which requires significant financial and human resources, I would like to support this process of clarifying the legislative framework and I therefore intend to vote in favour of this resolution as it stands.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's Committee on the Environment intends to have Parliament adopt a political resolution that would require the European Commission to adopt legislation calling for a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat in processed foods. This request raises serious economic and internal market concerns. Although the Commission's impact assessment shows that 90 % of consumers are interested in the country of origin of meat products, 80 % of these would not support the indication of the country of origin of the meat if this would lead to an increase in the consumer price of foodstuffs. If the mandatory marking were introduced, the costs of meat processors would increase significantly by 30 %. Processors would pass on all the additional costs (90 % of these costs according to the Commission) to consumers, and the impact assessment therefore foresks for a consumer price increase of 6-9 %. Therefore, the country of origin marking should not be introduced on meat products. The majority of these products are typically purchased by poorer people, who would no longer be able to buy these products after a significant price increase. Finally, I must point out that last year's food fraud, known as the 'horsemeat scandal', could not be prevented, despite the fact that beef has been compulsory since the 2000 BSE crisis. I therefore ask the Commission, irrespective of the EP's position, to refrain from introducing a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Any EU regulation that raises product costs, and thus costs for consumers, and imposes administrative obligations on SMEs, creates opposition and increases aversion to the EU – so we should be guided primarily by common sense when making decisions. I believe that we should pay particular attention to two issues when working on the design of the rules on the labelling of the country of origin of meat. There is no doubt that food safety should be at the forefront, so that the customer can be sure that the product purchased meets all the standards and that its consumption does not have any negative health effects. Wherever meat is used in production, food safety should be prioritised.  The second point concerns the studies carried out, from which it appears that the main criterion on the basis of which consumers shop is the price conditions of the goods. In this case, we should focus on solutions that make the products offered for sale within a price range acceptable to consumers, especially as a significant proportion of farm income is spent on meeting current food maintenance and purchase needs. Let us therefore consider whether the summary bill for the introduction of the food labelling requirement is no higher than the benefits we can obtain and whether it will not oppose internal market principles and pro-consumer attitudes.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. –On Wednesday, the European Parliament decided to demand a proposal from the Commission to mark the country of origin of the meat in processed meat products such as sausages and eines. At present, EU legislation requires that the country of origin of beef should be indicated for the place of birth, rearing and slaughter. In the spring, a regulation will enter into force extending the label to meat from other animals. Processed meat is currently outside the labelling requirement. Traceability of food origin increases transparency and thus improves consumer confidence in products and also increases the ability to monitor product quality and animal welfare. The horsemeat scandals must never happen again. The country of origin is also one of the most important information consumers want to know about the meat product they buy.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – 90% of European consumers want to know the origin of meat ingredients in processed foods. The figure is based on the observations of a number of consumer organisations, but also on a survey carried out by the Commission. The origin of meat in general is of paramount importance to CONSUMERS in the EU. Some producers have therefore accepted the labelling of the origin of meat on a voluntary basis, while others do not provide this information to consumers on the grounds that labelling the origin of meat in processed foods could lead to an increase of 15-50 % in the prices of the end product. Consumer surveys, on the other hand, quantified estimated average price increases in the order of units of cents. I believe that increasing the transparency and clarity of information can contribute to restoring European consumers' confidence in food on the European market. At the same time, however, it is important to ensure that the increase in information on food packaging does not negatively affect the availability of these products. Since the data on the possible impact on the final price of products vary diametrically, does the Commission have a precise cost analysis in the case of the mandatory introduction of origin labelling in processed products?

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – Origin labelling provides consumers with the possibility to make informed choices about the food they wish to purchase and consume. Consumers’ interest in the origin of their food has grown over the years, meat products being no exception, as most studies show that the origin of meat is usually in the top five aspects influencing purchase options. Origin labelling for foodstuffs with meat as an ingredient would answer concerns related to food quality, food safety, and animal welfare, but also economic and environmental concerns. Considering that, compared to the EU/Non-EU labelling option only specific country of origin labelling could provide meaningful information, it is only in the latter case that introducing new labelling measures would make sense. Nevertheless, considering the anticipated costs associated with such measures, maybe the Commission should explore the possibility of limiting the scope of application of such a labelling measure so as to ensure that consumers have enough information, but at the same time producers would not have to bear an excessive burden.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. –I see it as my duty for the European Union to guarantee the quality and safety of food by law. If I thought that by mandatory indication of the origin of meat ingredients for processed foods we would improve their quality, I would certainly vote in favour of the motion for a resolution. Even if it means a higher price. But I don't think so. Which one of us can claim today that meat from one state or another guarantees quality? I'm sure none of us would dare say that. The reasons for labelling the origin of meat in meat products, which have been raised here today, such as the choice, the knowledge of origin, the monitoring of the entire production and distribution chain, are all legitimate interests and reasons that may mean greater comfort for consumers. However, they should not be a reason to place a new obligation on each manufacturer. As you know, many manufacturers are already taking advantage of this interest in consumers and offering origin labelling of meat components as an above standard for their products. Every consumer can therefore already choose the manufacturer who will offer it this above standard. As part of the competitive advantage, they will surely increase. However, I see my duty in ensuring and promoting quality for every consumer, which is not directly linked to the place of origin.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Milan ZVER
text: Last year, we celebrated the 20th anniversary of the single market in the European Union, based on the free movement of people, goods, capital and services. A lot has been done, there's a lot to go on. As early as 2010, the European Commission announced the removal of tax barriers for European Union citizens in a cross-border environment. Unfortunately, this area is far from settled today. For example, Slovenia has a higher tax rate and fewer tax breaks than other members. Commuters working in Austria must pay around two net monthly income tax pay per year in Slovenia. They also face other problems due to non-compliance at EU level, such as in the area of child benefit.  These workers are in a discriminatory position. As labour mobility is hampered, the european Union's economic growth is also being hampered, so I ask the European Commission once again when it will act or whether it can recommend member states to withhold the recovery of disproportionately high surcharges in the run-up to the regulation of the problem at EU level.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my own territory is one of the most depressed in Europe. In southern Italy, particularly in the province of Caserta, in what was once referred to as "working land", we have been witnessing for years an unriped industrial desertification, with the disappearance of labour-intensive companies such as Firema, Jabil, Indesit, Ixfin, former Olivetti and today also the Ericsson case. The Swedish company has in fact started an operation to sell the branch of activity of the Marcianise headquarters to a subcontractor, the US multinational Jabil, putting at risk about 1,000 workers. The European Union must relaunch its industrial policy with forms of intervention which, also taking into account the globalisation of the markets, guarantee a system of rules and aid capable of affecting and avoiding distortions in localisation. The aim must be to relaunch a strong and competitive European production system in the world. Urgent measures must be taken to defend the entrepreneurial fabric and work, discouraging relocations and divestitures, such as the one that Ericsson is about to carry out in the province of Caserta, capable only of causing further damage to the social and economic fabrics already seriously compromised.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the recent blackmailing decision by the European Central Bank to stop accepting Greek government bonds in Eurosystem operations is illegal and abusive, as it violates the provisions of European Union law and was taken for purely political reasons in order to force Greece to follow the orders of the Troika and the lenders, including the ECB itself. The ECB has now become a state in state. It is supposedly an independent institution of monetary policy, while at the same time it is a member of the Troika and also a lender of Greece, resulting in a conflict of interest within it. All the European Central Bank is interested in is continuing to profit at the expense of the poor Greek people, demanding that the Greek government bonds that the Central Bank itself bought at a 40 per cent discount be paid at their nominal value. But let Mr. Draghi that his ultimatum will not pass. The Greek people will continue to fight against the Troika for the write-off of the shameful debt.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, in Ireland we have a joke that if a stranger asks you for directions and the route is very complicated, you might answer by saying: ‘if I were you I would not start from here’. Well it is the same with the current crisis: a currency still not fit for purpose, a Europe where trust between countries and citizens is fast eroding, and politicians in all Member States make promises they cannot keep and/or tell their edited version of the truth to their citizens.  Yes, there were reckless borrowers and some lived beyond their means, but equally, there were reckless lenders and tons of cash fuelled by low interest rates to suit some Member States flowed across European borders in a torrent. Those who were lucky enough to grab a lifeboat should now help the other survivors to clamber aboard or at least throw a lifebuoy.  The solution will not be just between Germany and Greece; we need a European solution – one that does not promote moral hazard but one that is sustainable for all Member States. Yes, we would prefer not to start from here, but we are here and we must start.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, the right to strike is a fundamental right which suffers an unprecedented attack at the international level with a clear anti-union purpose. On 18 February, in a context of questioning the right to strike by employers, supported by related governments, the International Trade Union Confederation convenes us to a day of action in defence of the right to strike, which will have our full support. In the specific case of the Spanish state, the protest is being criminalized and acts of mass repression against trade unionists and strikers are taking place. There are more than three hundred people who are prosecuted. On Wednesday 11th, eight trade unionists from Airbus' business committee were pending trial, for whom eight years in prison are being stried. This trial has been postponed because the Public Prosecutor's Office has refused to reduce the request for punishment, contradicting public statements made by the Spanish Minister of Justice. We demand respect for fundamental rights and international standards. Europe cannot be inhibited by such attacks on the freedom of workers. Strike is not a crime.

name: Julia REDA
text: Mr President, without encryption, every e-mail one sends and every word one types into a website can easily be intercepted, read and even modified. Encryption is essential to protect the integrity of the communications of individuals and businesses in Europe. This is especially important given how ineffective the European Union has been at stopping the surveillance of its people politically. After the Snowdon revelations, EU governments told people to rely on encryption. It is unacceptable to call their right to use encryption into question now. We must promote encryption technologies and ensure that they are available to everyone. We must reject government backdoors in security software. Such backdoors can always be used by criminals as well. We must reject mass data retention. We know that blanket surveillance only increases the size of the haystack; it does not help in finding the needles. We must also reject internet censorship in the form of secret website-blocking lists. The freedom and openness of our society must not be compromised.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is unacceptable that in 2015, after countless complaint petitions, questions, meetings, working groups and investigative trips, it has not yet been possible to define precisely the meaning that each Member State and each jurisdiction must give to the expression 'good of the child' or 'best interests of the child'. It is unacceptable that some Member States, especially Germany, should understand this interest as a relationship between the child and the German parent alone, as a use of the German language only and as a systematic short-, medium- or long-term cancellation of contact with the parent and the whole non-German family. This interpretation of the best interests of the child leads the courts of that country to issue judgments of German law but in violation of fundamental rights and those recognised in the European Charter. Any attempt to clarify this point has been blocked in the name of subsidiarity proper to family law, thus trampling underfoot, in a European Union that stands as a champion of the law, the most basic human rights.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: The Commission has launched a special investigation into the practices of Belgian governments in relation to individual tax agreements with multinationals. There would be a serious distortion of order, excess profit, namely a distortion of competition within the internal market. One question that arises is: what is the position of the current Belgian Government? Apart from the announcement that she will cooperate with the investigation, no clear position has yet been taken. Another question that the Commission must answer is: is the 'Belgium' case more serious than that of other Member States applying tax-favouring practices? Once again, we are facing one of the disadvantages of the European concept: the more unity one creates, the more natural competition between Member States becomes a so-called violation of the idea of unity. In this case, therefore, we are talking about more unity and further fiscal integration. It will never end, and it will continue to rage around until there is no more freedom. All this has little to do with democracy.

name: József NAGY
text: Dear Mr President, You'd think the time for concept trials in the European Union was over! Unfortunately, this is not the case in Slovakia. Malina Hedvig's name is already known in this house. In 2006, a Hungarian schoolgirl from Slovakia was beaten for speaking Hungarian on the street. A few days later, the political leadership made her a victim by accusing her of fabricated the whole story and accusing her of perjury. Since then, Malina Hedvig has been given the benefit of the doubt by the Strasbourg court, and the citizens of Slovakia, regardless of nationality, have protested in bulk in favour of her. And the good news finally came recently, that back home, the court of first instance rejected the perjury indictment. Yet the nine years of constant abuse did not end there. Last week, it was revealed that the state's attorney's office had appealed and would take Malina Hedvig back into the dock. My message to Slovakia and to the other EU Member States is that not only the politician, but also the state itself, in which a citizen can be vilied for reasons of vote-getting or alleged interest in state security, is completely discredited.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my concern that the recent attacks in Paris could be used to delay, once again, Romania's entry into the Schengen area.  There is no link between free movement within the Schengen area and what happened in Paris. On the contrary, it is time for the Schengen countries to understand that the extension of this area can strengthen the security and defence zone in Europe. We cannot allow our European values of freedom, dignity and solidarity to be put at stake by provocative acts perpetrated by extremists, whose aim is to separate us, to make us feel in danger and to make us become suspicious within our own borders.  I therefore hope for a quick decision on Romania's inclusion in the Schengen area, which would make it possible to affirm, once again, that the threat of terrorism will not weaken us.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Yesterday in a neighbouring country, Slovakia, hundreds of thousands of people voted in a national referendum to defend the rights of the family, to defend the natural marriage regime as a union between a man and a woman, to defend the right of parents to raise their children according to their parental responsibility and conscience. This vote has a national dimension. It did not have legal status, but we here in the European Parliament in particular should be aware of one thing: that almost twice as many people voted in favour of the rights of the family, in favour of the natural marriage regime, than for the entire national representation of Slovakia in the European Parliament. This shows how important this voice is to us. Slovakia has told Europe that there are millions of people living everywhere in our countries who want to live according to the principles of the civilization of life, who want to live in respect for the rights of the family. And for this we all, the whole of Europe, owe the Slovak people great gratitude.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: Mr. President, colleagues, standardization, joint production and joint procurement of military equipment would mean cutting costs and strengthening the defence of Europe as a whole and each of its countries individually. In 2008, the European Defence Agency set targets for joint procurement and joint investments in research and technology.  Since that 2008, however, these objectives have not only not been achieved, but the share of joint procurement and research has fallen. Joint procurement from 21% to 15%, and joint investments in research and technology from 16% to 10%. In the modern world, when there are so many crisis hot spots and conflicts at our external borders, this is really worrying data, and therefore I call on the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission to find urgent solutions to improve European defence cooperation.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, the result of the elections in Greece has highlighted in the most tragic way the impasse of the policies in place in Europe. They have shown that Europe's biggest problem is not economic but democracy and respect for its institutions. The Greek people have shouted what everyone sees, that the policy that is being implemented is weakening the peoples by endangering the Construction of Europe. But those who are enriched by the crisis prove that they are dangerous both for democracy and for the cohesion of Europe. With extreme positions like that elections have no significance for the policy applied and blackmailing Draghi-style decisions they reproduce the impasse. It is a devastating mistake for everyone here to think that the problem is Greek. It concerns the whole of Europe and we are all obliged to assume our responsibilities and respond to what Europe we want. The Europe of democracy, equality, solidarity and dignity, the Europe of the peoples is not built with such policies.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: The transition of the Member States of the European Union to a circular economy is very important in making resources and raw materials more resourceful, and if we are to achieve greater European Union independence in the field of raw materials, it is necessary to promote a circular economy based on reuse and high-quality recycling of waste, rather than withdrawing this circular economy programme from the programme for the next period, as this Commission has done. I hope that the Commission's statement that this does not actually mean withdrawing this project, but that it is ready for a holistic approach, is not just an excuse for this project to be permanently withdrawn and not to join the investment cycle, because the cyclical and circular economy also means the possibility of creating jobs.  And it would be unacceptable to withdraw the waste-free Europe programme from the Commission's programme, because waste, waste is becoming a growing problem because of its disposal, rather than becoming a source and also a means of recycling and renewable sourcing.

name: James CARVER
text: Mr President, the EU Framework Directive on Waste, like so many outpourings of bureaucracy from these institutions, uses a one-cap-fits-all approach to the problem of waste disposal, despite the ways that different Member States have traditionally approached this subject. I am often asked both by constituents and journalists what impact the EU really has on my country, and I can think of no better example of the EU’s inflexibility than by highlighting the development of a new incinerator in Worcestershire in response to this directive. In these worrying times of austerity and public service cuts, I am appalled that Council tax payers where I live and work in Worcestershire and Herefordshire have been saddled with a project lifetime cost to the tune of GBP 1.6 billion. There can be no doubt that this incinerator will become an enormous financial burden to my constituents.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I apologise for being late, I was at a meeting of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.  Ladies and about! In communist countries, the Wolf Act was a phenomenon, which in 1988 made Polish most liberal country in Europe, including Western Europe. This law is not there today, but it has been drafted in a new version and will be submitted to Commissioner Bieńkowska tomorrow. It may also be possible to make the Country of Economic Freedom out of the European Union. Furthermore, I believe that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr President, I think this was about Carthage, and the European Union is not a country.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I would like to point out that ammunition depots exploded repeatedly last autumn near the Czech-Slovak border in Vrběice in the Zlín Region. The former military buildings were rented by the Czech state as ammunition depots to private companies and in as yet unexplained circumstances two of them exploded, two people died, several thousand people had to be evacuated, the damage to the life, health and property of citizens and legal entities is enormous. The Vrbětice case has shown that the Czech State has neglected the protection of its citizens considerably in this area and its legislation is inadequate in many ways. However, EU rules also contain shortcomings. By June 2015, EU countries are to transpose the Major Accident Risk Control Directive into their law. However, this does not apply to military and paramilitary objects, so even this European regulation would not apply to the case of ammunition depots in Vrběice. The legislation also does not deal with the transport of these materials from hazardous warehouses, information to residents and emergency preparedness.  I therefore ask the European Commission, also in view of the Vrbětice case and its cross-border dimension, to re-analys EU law and to propose an amendment to European legislation to further protect the civilian population, increase its participation in preventing accidents of hazardous chemicals and ensure an adequate role for municipalities.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: In the light of the escalation of the Ukraine-Russia conflict, the decision of the European Union's foreign ministers to extend sanctions against certain individuals on our ban list for a further six months and to introduce new economic sanctions is to be welcomed. However, in preparing sanctions, we must be aware that Russia poses a threat not only to Ukrainian sovereignty, but also to European unity. The growing support for Russia and some of its actions within the European Union is no accident. Therefore, sanctions should ensure that parties or politicians do not receive Russian financial support at national or European level in order to serve Russian political purposes, thereby undersouring common European values. It is therefore my proposal that the incorporation of this consideration into the new sanctions would not only allow us to put pressure on the Kremlin to withdraw all support from separatist groups, but would also help to ensure that Russia cannot influence European or Member State decisions by financing the extreme political forces of individual Member States.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to draw the European Commission's attention to the very difficult situation of milk farmers in my country, Poland. As a result of the Russian embargo, milk purchase prices fell by more than 20% compared to the pre-embargo period, while at the same time farmers were fined EUR 46 million for exceeding production limits in the 2013/2014 quota year. And all indications are that for the next quota year 2014/2015 these penalties will reach an astronomical amount of EUR 200 million.  The burden on the most efficient dairy farms with such high penalties, while at the same time a serious decrease in the purchase price of milk in Poland will inevitably lead to their massive bankruptcies. At the same time, the European Commission has decided to support milk producers in the Baltic states and Finland with a so-called EUR 28 million milk package, while milk producers in Poland are not taking this package. I therefore ask the Commission not to collect penalties for the quota year 2014/2015, especially if the milk quotas of the whole Union are not exceeded. From 1 April this year, the limit on milk production is abolished.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Mr President, populists cannot impose debt default, but Greek citizens who are suffering the most from rulers, especially those of the past, need relief. This is obvious and necessary. Moreover, the Troika lacks legal support and acts outside the Treaties; and worse, this is a factual power that is not subject to democratic control of European citizenship. It has also imposed measures that have increased unemployment and poverty in the countries concerned, obviating the social objectives of the European Union. It does not encourage Europeanism, on the contrary. Choosing between populists and the Troika is a false mirage. It's not about supporting one thing or another. I encourage this House to tackle unpayable debt without breaching the European Treaties and Commitments.
