Defending the values of European construction as a compass tells us that economic wisdom, democratic control of institutions and solidarity must go hand in hand, and we must not let citizens down.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Mr President, Catalonia has begun a process to decide democratically its future, involving millions of people.  Judge Santiago Vidal, along with other jurists, in his free time and without following anyone's commission, has prepared a text of Constitution for discussion and comment. According to the procedure followed so far, the highest body of Spanish judges will decide in the coming days the expulsion from the judicial career of Judge Vidal. I would like to denounce the Spanish Government and the judiciary here for this attack on freedom of expression, enshrined in Article 11 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and article 20 of the Spanish Constitution. The Spanish state is in a dangerous democratic recession in which the division and independence of powers disappear.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, in view of the informal summit, I think we should be concerned that in the European Union we have extended freedoms but, nevertheless, issues of identity, culture and religion arise, which are the cause of conflict, racist phenomena and terrorist attacks. In order to deal specifically with terrorism, my view is that a common cross-border dialogue is needed. It is not conceivable that the European Parliament does not have a voice, a resolution against terrorism, because this, with unity, makes up the need for a common counter-terrorism strategy, a strategy which will also address the phenomenon in the field of prevention, where it also concerns education, and especially in the area of repression. Otherwise, we cannot control the phenomenon, because we all know that terrorism does not recognise borders.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Mr President, in two days the conflict in Ukraine will be debated again in this plenary. The role of the European Union, the Commission and Parliament must be at the forefront of efforts to succeed the negotiations with Russia and our messages heard. We want dialogue, not ultimatums, partnership, not sanctions. Guns don't solve conflicts, they bring violence, death, destruction. That's the cruel lesson we learned 70 years ago. In Europe, another risk is added - a new humanitarian crisis. After the thousands seeking refuge in the European Union from the conflicts in Africa and the Middle East, new refugee waves from Ukraine will be directed to the eastern borders, which Europe will find difficult to deal with, especially countries at the external borders. We must support Mrs Mogherini's efforts to find a peaceful outcome and find a compromise solution. Her place is among the negotiators. I insist on guaranteeing the rights of minorities in Ukraine and ending mandatory mobilisation for participation in armed formations and military action.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: In 2013, after a gradual reduction in roaming surcharge, the European Commission put forward a proposal to abolish roaming surcharge. This was supported by a large majority in the European Parliament, and we did so in 2014. We would have been waiting for the Council's approval and support, which was promised for December, but this did not happen. Moreover, the first proposal of the Latvian Presidency to renegotiate this framework was to come forward with a new proposal, which is that there is a basic framework for the exchange of information, and to this end it is only possible to make a phone call or even to initiate an SMS or use the Internet. In other words, it is a very new proposal. I think that this is a let-down of 500 million EU citizens, that they cannot enjoy this cost reduction. I respectfully ask the President to listen to the Council so that the original proposal is supported, and I ask the Commission to listen to its original proposal. Because if this did not happen, the Latvian Presidency's proposal would initiate a whole new situation that would not be good for anyone, least of all EU citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: The current international context underpins a key european Union need to invest heavily in strengthening relations with partners in the non-Community area.  In this respect, the EU's border areas are all the more in need of investment. The vital infrastructure for the EU's interconnection with the surrounding regions must also be supported by the Strategic Investment Plan presented by the Commission. The correct targeting of European resources towards the development of large transport infrastructure in Eastern Europe is an obligation that decision-makers have in the coming period. Statistically, investments in transport infrastructure have the highest multiplication rate of all investments.  In addition, investment in motorways, railways, ports or airports helps local economies to grow and creates the much-needed jobs that we have all promised to provide to our citizens, especially young people. The strategic priority for the development of EU border areas must be to start from major investments in infrastructure.  Romania alone currently has proposals for infrastructure projects worth 62 billion euros.  If we refer to the EUR 23 billion available, we come to the conclusion that we need more money directed into this sector.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, the International Court of Justice in The Hague ruled last week regarding Croatia's lawsuit against Serbia, which clearly confirms that Serbia has pursued criminal policy on Croatian territory and that the war in Croatia was provoked from Belgrade and was an instrument of Belgrade's policy for the realization of Greater Serbia, and that Belgrade is responsible for crimes against humanity committed on Croatian territory. If the Court has not found that it was genocide, it does not mean that it did not find that the crimes were taking place, that Serbia has responsibility for what happened in Croatia. Unfortunately, various NGOs in both Serbia and Croatia are trying to relativize the verdict and crimes and spread the thesis that no one is to blame. This verdict is very clear and in paragraph 246 it clearly states that the Court agrees with the ICTY's conclusions on Serbia's activities against humanity in Croatia.  Vukovar, Škabrnja, Dubrovnik and places where civilians were tortured and killed and even UNESCO protected cultural monuments, are not recognized by the Court as a place of implementation of the policy of destruction, but the legitimacy of the military-gendarmerie action Storm that forever abolished Krajina and ensured the end of the war in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina has been confirmed once again.  The past is a burden serbian authorities will have to face if they want to become part of a European family. Here I think about finding the missing, opening archives of the former Yugoslavia and yugoslav people's army, return of kidnapped art, border on the Danube, the right of national minorities, but also the abolition of the disputed law on universal jurisdiction for war crimes on the territory of the former Yugoslavia.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in my province of Seville is the American military base of Morón, considered in southern Europe as strategic, either by the mission to combat Ebola or, right now, by the jihadist threat. And as 240 workers are fired, 3,000 new Marines are announced. And what does the Spanish government do? The Government of Spain negotiates with the United States to amend the international treaty behind its workers with a total lack of transparency. Today, I want to be the voice of these workers in the European Parliament and denounce this nonsense, as well as ask the European institutions to call for transparency in these negotiations concerning European security; that workers are reinstated from the base and equated in rights to other workers from other bases in Europe, because the number of American, American, while fewer European workers are increasing. Especially behind the back of a region already punished by unemployment.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking At the end of January, news emerged of France signing a bilateral agreement with Russia renewing exports of pigs, pig fat and pig offal to the country. Despite Mr Hogan's subsequent assurances that there would be no bilateral agreements with Russia to ease the embargo, I find this very worrying. Breaking EU solidarity and allowing Russia to choose the partners from which it will buy selected products, while leaving its market closed to producers from other countries, would be extremely damaging to the entire European Union, because unity and consistency are our strength. If we deprive ourselves of this advantage, we run the risk of being an unreliable and weak partner, which, especially in the current political situation, we cannot afford.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Mr President, last week the United Kingdom’s House of Commons voted to permit the genetic modification of humans as the first nation to do so worldwide. It is ethically and legally unacceptable to permit the creation of embryos with DNA from three parents. There is no such medical technique or treatment which could permit us to cross this internationally agreed principle of non-modification of the human germ line.  Therefore I would like to remind our British colleagues of their commitment to comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights as well as European legislation on clinical trials, both of which prohibit heritable modifications to the human genome. Last week, 50 MEPs signed a letter of profound concern over this technique called mitochondrial replacement and this week a new initiative to condemn such a breach was launched again in Parliament. Let us say a strong ʽnoʼ to designer babies.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you, Mr President, for your important speech. I wanted to say that this was the last speaker in our debate. I would like to thank all the speakers very much, but above all the translators who have shown quite a lot of flexibility, because we have agreed to work until 22.00 and you are working longer. I therefore thank you on behalf of all the ladies and gentlemen.
